entry.title: Flow Builder Plus: What Usually Stops Cash Flows from Getting Created
entry.content:
If you work with Cash Management in SAP S/4HANA, you‚Äôve probably run into this at least once: a document gets posted, but nothing shows up in FQM_FLOW. Flow Builder Plus runs without errors, yet no cash flows are created. Customers raise cases on this all the time, and the pattern is usually the same.

Here‚Äôs the thing. Flow Builder Plus is reliable, but it‚Äôs strict about the conditions under which it generates flows. Miss one key detail, and the flow quietly disappears somewhere in the pipeline. This post walks through the common reasons why it happens, what they really mean, and how to check them without getting lost in technical rabbit holes.


1. Flow Type Assignment: The First Thing to Check

If Flow Type isn‚Äôt assigned to a line item, Flow Builder Plus simply won‚Äôt pick it up.
Cash flow generation depends entirely on this field.

Only these Flow Type ranges actually create flows in One Exposure:

  • 90* Actual
  • 80* Bank clearing
  • 70* Payment Request clearing
  • 60* Customer/Vendor
  • 50* Others

If your document doesn‚Äôt fall into one of these buckets, Flow Builder Plus ignores it. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important to confirm Flow Type is present in BSEG and correctly categorized. Refer to Flow Types | SAP Help Portal for understanding how Flow Type is updated in BSEG.

If you suspect Flow Types got missed, run the report FQM_UPDATE_FLOW_TYPE to refresh them in BSEG.

Also check whether Flow Types exist in VFCLMFLOWLVL. If not, run FQM_INIT_FLOW_CAT_KF to push the catalog into the system.

2. Line-Item Status: Cleared Items and Zero Amounts

Flow Builder Plus doesn‚Äôt generate flows for cleared items unless the Flow Type is 90*.
So, if BSEG-AUGBL is filled, that line is already settled and becomes irrelevant for most flow types.

Zero amounts are also a blocker. If WRBTR or DMBTR is zero, there‚Äôs no cash-relevant movement to represent, and Flow Builder Plus won‚Äôt create anything.

3. IBU Flows: The Quiet Showstopper

This one catches many users off guard.
If an IBU flow already sits in FQM_FLOW for the same G/L or technical ID and company code, the system won‚Äôt generate another flow for earlier documents.

The key comparison is:

  • IBU flow‚Äôs transaction date in FQM_FLOW
    vs
  • The document‚Äôs posting date and planning date

If the IBU flow‚Äôs transaction date is later, the document gets skipped.
For an IBU flow, the TRANSACTION_OWNER will always be 'IBU'. 

4. Aggregation Effect: Why Everything Drops to Zero After FQM_AGGREGATE_FLOWS

After running FQM_AGGREGATE_FLOWS, some users notice that Flow Builder Plus or Flow Builder Plus 2 suddenly generates zero flows. This is expected behavior in certain cases.

SAP has detailed this in KBA 3679718, but the simple version is: once flows are aggregated, Flow Builder sees no new granular items to generate for actuals.

5. Start Date for One Exposure: A Small Setting With a Big Impact

In S/4HANA OP 2023, there‚Äôs a configuration for defining the start date for One Exposure.
If you‚Äôve set a date there, any actual flow prior to that date will not show up in FQM_FLOW.

This setting lives here:
SPRO ‚Üí Financial Supply Chain Management ‚Üí Cash and Liquidity Management ‚Üí Cash Management ‚Üí Data Setup ‚Üí Define Start Date for One Exposure

6. Liquidity Analysis Settings: Conditions That Must Be Met

If your system uses Liquidity Analysis, two checks matter:

  • Cash Scope must be set to Full Scope
  • Business function FIN_FSCM_CLM must be active in SFW5

Without these, Flow Builder Plus can‚Äôt update flows the way Liquidity Analysis expects.
Also make sure the prerequisites in KBA 3444282 are followed so automatic updates to FQM_FLOW actually trigger.

7. Cash Position: Workflow Linkage Matters

For cash position scenarios, automatic flow creation depends on workflow linkage.
Check SWETYPV and activate the linkage as described in KBA 3193587. If this isn‚Äôt active, cash position data never reaches FQM_FLOW.

8. MM Flows: The Usual Points That Get Missed

MM flows have their own pattern of issues. When Flow Builder Plus is run manually and still no MM flows show up, the following are usually the reasons:

  • The MM source application isn‚Äôt active
  • The PO or PR doesn‚Äôt have a vendor/supplier assigned
  • The vendor doesn't have Planning Level and Planning Group

Without those details, Flow Builder Plus has no basis to generate MM-related flows.
Also note that when a PO or PR is created, the entry first goes to FCLM_MM_STAGING. The workflow linkage (KBA 3193587) then moves it into FQM_FLOW. If that linkage isn‚Äôt active, nothing happens downstream.

Closing Thoughts

Most missing-flow issues don‚Äôt require deep debugging. They come down to Flow Type gaps, cleared or zero-amount line items, IBU conflicts, workflow linkage, or Liquidity Analysis settings that aren‚Äôt fully wired.

Once you‚Äôve seen these patterns a few times, you can predict exactly where the break is. And when FQM_FLOW stays empty, working through these areas usually leads you straight to the reason.

entry.title: Fixed Assets migration with India Localization
entry.content:
Migration Report Guide: Mass Update of India Asset Fields in SAP

Managing fixed assets in SAP can become challenging during data migration or statutory updates. For India-specific requirements, SAP provides three dedicated migration reports to handle asset block data, asset assignment, and Written Down Value (WDV) updates.

This blog walks you through the details with step-by-step instructions, sample formats, and key points to remember.

Overview of Migration Transactions

Process

Transaction Code

Purpose

Upload Asset Block Data

J1INBLK

Create/Upload Asset Block information

Assign Assets to Blocks

J1INBLKTOAST

Link existing assets to their respective blocks

Update Opening WDV

J1INTRNS

Enter opening Written Down Values for blocks

 

  1. Uploading Asset Block Data ‚Äì J1INBLK

Asset Block details can be uploaded into the system using a spreadsheet

Steps

  1. Execute transaction J1INBLK.
  2. Prepare the spreadsheet in the given template format.
  3. Upload the file into the system.

While uploading Asset Block Data, if the field ‚ÄòPut to Use Date‚Äô needs to be considered, add a column ‚ÄòPut to Use Date‚Äô in the spreadsheet and mark it with ‚ÄòX‚Äô.

File to use: J1INBLK.csv.  Refer to the screenshot provided in the attachments for format guidance.

 

Steps to Cross Verify Data Uploaded via J1INBLK

  1. Check in CIN Customizing Table
  • The data uploaded through J1INBLK is stored in CIN-specific tables.
  • Validate whether all the blocks uploaded appear here with correct:
    • Block Code
    • Block Description
    • Depreciation Rate (%)
    • Useful Life (if maintained)
  1. Check Through Transaction
    • Alternatively, check via J1INBLKTOAST, which lists available blocks when you try to assign assets. If the uploaded block is visible there, upload was successful.
  1. Cross-Check with Asset Assignment
    • Go to J1INBLKTOAST and try assigning an asset.
    • If your uploaded block is selectable, it means the block has been created correctly.
  2. Reconcile With Input File
    • Compare your original upload file (spreadsheet or text file) with entries in J_1IITMBLK.
    • Number of records and block details should match.
  3. Assigning Assets to Blocks ‚Äì J1INBLKTOAST

This function lets you assign assets blocks with ease.

Steps

  1. Execute transaction J1INBLKTOAST.
  2. Prepare the CSV file with asset-to-block assignments.
  3. Upload using the given template.

File to use: J1INBLKTOAST_Template.csv. Refer to the screenshot provided for format guidance.

 

 

Keep the field ‚ÄòPut to use date‚Äô blank if you want to upload the file for assignment of Block key to Asset master.

Steps to Cross-Verify J1INBLKTOAST Report Data

  1. Compare with Uploaded File / Migration Template
    1. Ensure each Asset Number (ANLN1/ANLN2) is mapped to the correct Block Key (from Income Tax blocks).
    2. Check if the count of records in your Excel/Upload file = records in report.
  2. Check in Asset Master (AS03 / AW01N)
    1. Open the asset in AS03.
    2. Go to India-specific fields tab ‚Üí confirm the Block assignment matches what you see in the J1INBLKTOAST output.
  3. Cross-Check with Asset Block Master (J1INBLK)
    1. Run J1INBLK to display block details.
    2. Verify whether the block code assigned in J1INBLKTOAST exists and is valid.
  4. Run Trial Reports
    1. Generate Depreciation / IT depreciation reports (like J1INTRN, J1INMIS, or custom reports).
    2. Check if assets are reflecting under the right block for calculation.
  5. Reconciliation Counts
    1. Number of assets in J1INBLKTOAST report should = number of assets you intended to assign.

 

  1. Updating Opening WDV ‚Äì J1INTRNS

With this transaction, the user can assign the Opening WDV for existing asset blocks.

  1. Execute transaction J1INTRNS.
  2. Prepare the CSV file with opening balances.
  3. Upload into the system.

File to use: J1INTRNS.csv Refer to the screenshot provided in the attachments for format guidance.

 


Important: Transaction date must be in format YYYYMMDD

Steps to Cross-Verify J1INTRNS

  1. Compare with Uploaded File
  • Check Block Key, Asset Block description, Opening WDV amount from your migration spreadsheet against the J1INTRNS report.
  • Ensure record counts match.
  1. Validate in Block Master (J1INBLK)
  • Run J1INBLK to confirm blocks exist and are valid.
  • Compare the WDV values updated in J1INTRNS against the balances in J1INBLK.
  1. Cross-Check Totals
  • Sum up all uploaded WDV amounts per block and compare with totals in J1INTRNS report output.
  • Totals should match exactly (unless any rounding adjustments are applied).
  1. Check Asset Assignment (J1INBLKTOAST)
  • Ensure assets linked to blocks (via J1INBLKTOAST) correctly roll up into the Opening WDV shown in J1INTRNS.
  1. Reconcile with Finance Books
  • Cross verify uploaded WDV balances with financial balances (FI-AA reports like AR02 / AW01N) for sanity check.
  • If total book WDV ‚â† tax WDV, document the difference (per Income Tax Act).
  1. Check Period/Year Validity
  • Confirm that WDV uploaded in J1INTRNS reflects in the correct Fiscal Year & Assessment Year.

Key Reminders

üîπ Always test in a sandbox / quality system before production uploads.
üîπ Validate all CSV data for accuracy and completeness.
üîπ Keep backup copies of original spreadsheets for audit purposes.
üîπ Document any errors and resolutions during testing for future reference.

Conclusion

With the help of J1INBLK, J1INBLKTOAST, and J1INTRNS, organizations can:

  • Upload Asset Block details,
  • Assign assets efficiently, and
  • Maintain correct Opening WDV values.

These migration reports simplify India-specific asset accounting and ensure compliance with statutory requirements.

entry.title: Building a Compelling S/4HANA Business Case: Beyond the Technical Upgrade
entry.content:
Preparing a robust business case for an SAP S/4HANA implementation is beyond a technical assessment. It is a strategic exercise aimed to define the organisation‚Äôs digital future. The move to SAP S/4HANA is considered a full scale transformation which requires considerations across organisation strategy, technology and financial viability. This blog is oriented to highlight critical aspects to be considered to build a compelling and approvable business case.

Strategic Alignment: ‚ÄúWhy Now‚Äù: 

The foundation of the business case requires clear articulation of how SAP S/4HANA will directly support and accelerate the business strategy. This has to go beyond replacing the ageing SAP ECC system.

  • Alignment with the business goals: Identify / Define the organisation‚Äôs key strategic objectives ‚Äì whether its increasing market share, effective cost management, building a resilient supply chain or to shift to a cloud first model. Map how SAP S/4HANA capabilities (e.g. process standardisation, embedded AI, embedded analytics, etc.) to these strategic objectives to demonstrate its necessity
  • Urgency Assessment: Define the ‚ÄúWhy Now‚Äù This could be the result of the need for an agile solution to meet the competitive pressures of the industry, ability to quickly integrate acquisitions or to replace a complex and costly SAP ECC solution.
  • Cloud Operating Model: The decision is tied to a cloud strategy. Evaluate your chosen Cloud Operating Model (SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud or Private Cloud or Sovereign Cloud). This decision has implications from a licensing, TCO, agility and governance of the target state. The business case must justify the chosen model based on factors like standardisation, required functionality and regulatory compliance.
  • Embedded AI and Intelligence: SAP S/4HANA is the core of the intelligent enterprise. The business case needs to proactively identify and quantify the value of embedded AI and process automation opportunities. This is a important consideration for definition of a target state and directly linked to the business benefits like productivity improvements, enhanced user experience and better decision making

Strategic Fit - Figure 1

Option Identification and Selection Criteria:

A credible business case must evaluate all the viable options to develop a proposed path bearing in mind the target state and not just the replacement of a single solution.

  • Identification of options:
    • Option 0: Do nothing: This will be the baseline for comparing any other options. However, there will be risks and costs associated with not moving both from a business and technology viewpoint. Ensure that they are highlighted within the business case
    • Option 1: Brownfield: Focused on technical migration of SAP ECC with SAP S/4HANA while retaining existing business processes and customisations. The option will require to incorporate the mandatory changes required as a result of the move to SAP S/4HANA, but it could also help to deliver minimal business benefits through improved UI and better analytics.
    • Option 2: Greenfield Implementation: An implementation approach focused on adoption of out of box capabilities and aligned with Clean Core Extensibility Framework
    • Option 3: Selective Data Transition: A hybrid approach between greenfield and brownfield oriented out of functional or geographic dependencies and business priorities
  • Selection and Ranking of Decision Criteria: Establish evaluation / decision making criteria to objectively compare the options under consideration. The criteria should be informed by strategic objectives, architecture principles and business priorities. Recommendation would be to use a weighted scoring matric to objectively assess the options. Some of the criteria which should be part of any business case are highlighted below:
    • Strategic Fit: Alignment with the strategic goals and future scalabiloty
    • Total Cost of Ownership: NPV, IRR and payback period over a 5-10 year period
    • Business Value: Quantitative and qualitative business benefits, generally against key performance indicators across critical business processes.
    • Time to Value: Speed of deployment and flexibility to adopt to change.
    • Risk Assessment: Commercial, Technical and Change Management risks

Cost Benefit Analysis - Figure 2

 

Target State Definition and Deployment Roadmap

This is the final section of the business case where the selected option is translated to a plan. It should be indicative of the link between the effort and the delivered business value.

  • Target State Architecture: Define a target state architecture aligned with the SAP strategy. It should clearly separate the digital core from other SAP and non SAP applications within the landscape. It should highlight the use of Clean Core by building extensions on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). This is a critical aspect of the architecture definition as it highlights readiness for future upgrades and TCO reduction. It should also highlight other critical components like data, security, analytics and infrastructure management.
  • Deployment Roadmap and Value Realisation: Develop a phased deployment roadmap leveraging the SAP Activate Methodology. SAP offers Activate methodologies for each of the transition options described above.
    • Roadmap should be broken down into clear project phases linked with key delivery milestones
    • Roadmap should be value driven. Develop architecture building blocks which will deliver the business value as well as consider the business and technology dependencies as part of the target state
    • Clear indication of the expected business value that will be realised across the different phases. This would link the project expenditure to the expected returns
  • Risk and Change Management: A specific section should be captured within the business case identifying the risks and the mitigation approaches. The risks could range from an organisation perspective, delivery perspective or technical perspective. Common examples include scope change, gap resolution or resource constraints). The plan should also highlight a well considered change management strategy to establish a clear communication plan and to ensure user adoption.

Deployment Roadmap - Figure 3

 

A well-constructed business case is a key instrument to mobilise the transformation, aligning the technical execution with strategic initiatives and clearly defined path to achieve business value. SAP Business Transformation and Advisory team within can assist you with the development of detailed business case for your SAP S/4HANA implementation.

Please feel to reach out to me for any more information.

entry.title: Understanding the UI5 Component Loading Error in CLM Fiori Apps
entry.content:
Sometimes you open a Fiori app and it stops right away. Instead of the usual screen, you get a message saying the UI5 component couldn‚Äôt be loaded. I‚Äôve seen customers raise incidents about this in CLM apps like Cash Flow Analyzer, but the reason isn‚Äôt specific to CLM.

In most cases, the browser just can‚Äôt load one required file, and that‚Äôs enough for the whole app to fail. Once you know what causes it, the fix is straightforward.

What the user sees

You click the tile, and the launchpad throws this message:
App could not be opened because the SAP UI5 component of the application could not be loaded.

Fiori Launchpad showing error

If you check the browser console, the system gives a more direct hint:
Failed to load UI5 component for navigation intent

For a CLM app like Cash Flow Analyzer, it may point to a specific file that couldn‚Äôt be loaded:
failed to load 'fin/cash/flow/analyzer/Component.js' from /sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/fin_flowanalyze/... 403 - Forbidden

Customers have reported this issue, and since I work with Cash and Liquidity Management apps, I see these cases as well. But the cause itself is not tied to CLM. It‚Äôs a basic UI5 loading issue that can happen with any Fiori app.

What‚Äôs actually happening

Every Fiori app needs its UI5 component to be reachable through an active ICF service. If that ICF node is inactive, the system blocks the request with a 403 ‚Äì Forbidden. The browser can‚Äôt load Component.js, and the app stops immediately.

The navigation intent tells the system which UI5 component to load. If the ICF node linked to that component is inactive after a system refresh, transport, or upgrade, the loading process ends right there.

Nothing else can continue until the service is active again.

A simple CLM example: Cash Flow Analyzer

In the Fiori apps reference library, Cash Flow Analyzer shows the UI5 component details along with the ICF path it depends on.
App reference library showing the ICF path
Open SICF, search for the service path of your Fiori app, and verify its status.
SICF Transaction
If the service is inactive, the path appears grey. This is usually the reason the browser can‚Äôt reach the UI5 component at runtime.
Inactive service
Activate the service, run the test again, and the app should load unless something else is missing upstream.

Node after activation

Why this helps

Knowing this check saves time. Before looking into authorizations or configuration, you can verify whether the system is even able to load the UI5 component. It‚Äôs a quick step that avoids unnecessary back-and-forth and helps users troubleshoot more confidently.

Closing thoughts

If you often work with CLM or other Fiori apps, it helps to compare the app reference library with what you see in SICF. Once you understand how they connect, this error becomes much easier to solve.

entry.title: Enhancing Migration Efficiency Through Controlled SUM DMO Table Splitting
entry.content:
Understanding Table Splitting in SUM DMO

In a DMO or Downtime Optimized DMO (doDMO) scenario, application table transfer occurs across specific SUM phases:

  • EU_CLONE_CP2STAB_RUN ‚Äì Uptime phase (DMO & doDMO)

  • EU_CLONE_MIG_OPTDMO_INI_RUN ‚Äì Uptime phase (doDMO only)

  • EU_CLONE_MIG_DT_RUN ‚Äì Downtime phase (DMO & doDMO)

The preparation and calculation of table split logic occurs in corresponding preparation phases, all of which operate during uptime. This design allows proactive configuration before the critical migration execution begins.

While standard SUM behavior is sufficient for most systems, extremely large tables may require enforced customization to ensure balanced workload distribution and better utilization of parallel R3load processes.

Real-Time Issue Faced

During S4HANA upgrade with migration, a large tables like BALDAT with table size of 150GB and other tables with large size consuming excessive time in the table splitting phase. 

As a result, SUM extended runtime and this behavior directly contributed to increased downtime (i.e. 28Hrs27mins) risk and inefficient resource utilization.

 

Strategic Intervention Applied

Instead of relying solely on default parameters, we introduced controlled overrides in SUM configuration files to optimize splitting behavior.

Table-Specific Custom Splitting

We explicitly defined split fields by creating the following configuration file:

<SUM_DIR>/abap/control/EUCLONEDEFS_ADD.LST
And added as shown in below screenshot.

Syntax used:

Inhibit splitting of a table:
<TABLENAME> nosplit
Split a table into a defined number of segments:
<TABLENAME> segmentsize=0.02
Note: The segmentsize value is calculated as 1 / <number_of_splits>.
For example, 0.02 represents 50 segments for the table.

This ensured SUM enforced controlled segmentation of the table into predefined buckets, enabling predictable workload distribution and stable split calculation behavior.

 

Results Achieved

Following this intervention:

  • Large tables were processed in controlled parallel segments

  • SUM phases stabilized significantly

  • Overall downtime reduced measurably compared to earlier dry runs

  • Resource utilization became more balanced and predictable

This strategic tweaking allowed us to ensure smoother system availability and meet strict business downtime SLAs.

Downtime without table splitting took 28Hrs27mins

Downtime with table splitting took 12Hrs27mins

 

Key Takeaways

  • SUM default behavior is reliable but may not suit extreme data volumes.

  • Manual parameter tuning should only be performed by experienced SAP consultants.

  • Real-time log analysis is essential to identify root causes in splitting failures.

  • Controlled split field definition can resolve non-ASCII and key field selectivity issues.

  • Optimized parallelism improves both uptime processing and downtime efficiency.

 

Conclusion

This experience highlights how intelligent optimization of SAP SUM table splitting can play a crucial role in achieving successful S/4HANA upgrades. By leveraging advanced configuration parameters responsibly, we transformed a potential bottleneck into a controlled and efficient migration process.

For consultants handling large-scale systems with high-volume tables, understanding and applying these optimizations can be the difference between extended outages and seamless transitions.

 

Reference

This implementation approach is aligned with guidance from SAP Note 3386079 ‚Äì SUM DMO scenarios: Manual Options for Table Splitting and Table Migration, which provides expert-level control options for influencing SUM table splitting and migration behavior.

entry.title: Aufbau einer Key-User-Community im SAP S/4HANA-Projekt bei Aalberts hydronic flow control
entry.content:
Kathleen Regener berichtet √ºber den Aufbau einer Key-User-Community in einem internationalen S/4HANA-Projekt. Die zentrale Erkenntnis: Eine Community braucht mehr als nur Infrastruktur ‚Äì sie braucht den richtigen Zeitpunkt, aktive Moderation und Key-User, die etwas Greifbares haben, um sich beteiligen zu k√∂nnen.

√úber das Projekt und die Ausgangssituation

Kathleen Regener, PMO und Lead Change Management bei Aalberts hydronic flow control, berichtete in der SAP Training und Change Kaffee-Ecke √ºber den Aufbau einer Key-User-Community im Rahmen der konzernweiten S/4HANA-Transformation. Das Unternehmen bietet ganzheitliche L√∂sungen f√ºr Heiz-, K√ºhl- und Sanit√§rsysteme in Geb√§uden an. Das Projekt umfasst die Abl√∂sung von 6 verschiedenen ERP-Systemen f√ºr insgesamt 800 Enduser.

Die Besonderheit: Die Key-User wurden nicht ausgew√§hlt, sondern konnten sich f√ºr das Projekt bewerben. Am Ende konnten √ºber 100 motivierte Key-User gewonnen werden, die die √Ñnderungen mittragen wollten. Diese wurden in lokale Key-User und Power User aufgeteilt. Die lokalen Key-User waren die Ansprechpartner f√ºr das Projektteam und wurden f√ºr ihre Rolle freigestellt. Die Power User unterst√ºtzten nach verf√ºgbarer Zeit.

Struktur der Key-User-Community

Das Projektteam bestand aus Domain Process Ownern (DPOs), Technical Process Ownern (TPOs) und den Key-Usern. F√ºr die Global Template Phase wurden zus√§tzlich Global Key-User aus den Niederlanden, Deutschland und Frankreich eingebunden, die in die Workstreams Warehouse, Sales, Production, Supply Chain und Finance aufgeteilt waren.

Abbildung 1: Struktur des Projektteams mit DPOs, TPOs, Key-Usern (Global und lokal) und Power Usern

Projektphasen und Rollout-Strategie

Nach der Template-Phase wurden die Global Key-User zu lokalen Key-Usern und im ersten Rollout in den Niederlanden und UK eingesetzt. Die √ºbrigen Key-User gingen in eine Projektpause.

Diese Projektpause warf zentrale Fragen auf:

  • Wie bleibt man mit allen in Kontakt?
  • Wie k√∂nnen die Key-User zu einem Team zusammenwachsen?
  • Wie k√∂nnen wir sicherstellen, dass wir alle relevanten Informationen mit allen teilen?
  • Wie teilt man Lessons Learned aus den einzelnen Waves?

Aufbau der Community-Infrastruktur

Die Entscheidung fiel auf den Aufbau einer Teams-basierten Community mit verschiedenen Kan√§len. Der Start erfolgte mit einem offiziellen Kick-Off f√ºr alle Key-User. Es wurde eine Hausordnung erstellt, die das Verhalten in der Community regelte. Die Key-User erhielten eine Teams-Schulung, um die Umgebung optimal nutzen zu k√∂nnen.

Inhalte der Key-User-Community

Die Community bot ein umfassendes Angebot:

Workshop-Unterlagen:

  • Stressmanagement
  • Umgang mit Widerst√§nden
  • Train-the-Trainer-Unterlagen

Dokumentationen:

  • Quick Reference Cards
  • Projekt- und SAP-Glossar
  • FAQ zu Projekt und S/4HANA
  • Rollenbeschreibungen

Kommunikation und Austausch:

  • Raum f√ºr Fragen
  • Raum f√ºr Erfolgsstories
  • Raum f√ºr Lessons Learned
  • Projektinformationen und Timeline
  • Zentraler Meeting Hub
  • Regelm√§√üige Communication Starter

Ein Feedback-Channel wurde eingerichtet. Fragen wurden so beantwortet, dass die Antworten f√ºr alle Key-User sinnvoll nutzbar waren und im gesamten Team geteilt wurden.

Herausforderungen in der Praxis

Trotz der umfassender Vorbereitung gestaltete sich der Start schwierig. Die Reaktionen auf Communication Starter beschr√§nkten sich meist auf ein Daumen-hoch. Nach einem halben Jahr lautete das Fazit: Wir hatten keine Community, sondern ein Publikum. Die Informationen wurden aufgenommen, aber es fand keine wirkliche Interaktion statt.

Die neun zentralen Herausforderungen

Kathleen identifizierte neun konkrete Herausforderungen:

  • Keine Reaktionen der Key-User an uns als Change Management
  • Doppelrolle (Projekt und Tagesgesch√§ft) f√ºhrte zu Zeitproblemen bei Key Usern
  • Die Community hat nicht gelebt - es gab keine echte Interaktion
  • Unsicherheit beim Teilen: Key-User aus Wave 1 wussten nicht, was sie mit anderen Key-Usern teilen k√∂nnen
  • Fehlende Fragestellung: Key-User aus inaktiven Waves wussten nicht, was sie fragen k√∂nnen
  • Projektinformationen konnten nicht geteilt werden, da teilweise noch keine Entscheidungen getroffen waren oder das System noch nicht fertig war
  • Regelm√§√üige Check-Ins wurden nicht genutzt, da sich Key-User noch nicht vom Projekt betroffen f√ºhlten
  • Unterschiedliches Onboarding von Key-Usern und Power Usern
  • Geringe Teilnahmequote an Umfragen

Die zentrale Erkenntnis war: Der Zeitpunkt f√ºr den Aufbau der Community war falsch gew√§hlt.

Lessons Learned und Anpassungen

Eine Umfrage zeigte, dass die Key-User Beispiele, Tipps und Best Practices wollten, ihnen aber nicht bewusst war, dass sie selbst Input liefern m√ºssten. Das Selbstbewusstsein, selbst zur Community beitragen zu k√∂nnen, fehlte.

Konkrete Anpassungen in Wave 2

Abbildung: Change Management Lessons Learned und implementierte Verbesserungen

Das Change Management implementierte acht zentrale Verbesserungen:

  1. Onboarding-Phase und Toolkit f√ºr Key-User der n√§chsten Wave
  • Alle betroffenen lokalen Key-User und Power User wurden zum Kick-Off eingeladen
  • Geb√ºndelte Informationen in Landessprache
  • Hausaufgaben und Systemzugriff f√ºr die Vorbereitungsphase
  1. Statt Umfragen f√ºr Lessons Learned ‚Üí feste Termine f√ºr Feedback
  • Gezielte Fragen in pers√∂nlichen Terminen
  • Mehr direktes Feedback
  1. Erh√∂hung der Kommunikationsfrequenz
  • Zwei bis drei Communication Starter pro Woche
  • Mehr Bewegung in der Community
  1. Auf Wunsch: Aufnahme der DPOs und TPOs
  • Mehr Sicherheit f√ºr Key-User
  • Direkter Zugang zu Entscheidungstr√§gern
  1. Bi-weekly Community Meeting ‚Üí monatliches Meeting
  • Nur f√ºr Key-User der aktuellen Wave
  • In Landessprache
  • Mit Vorab-Fragen √ºber den Feedback-Kanal
  1. Einf√ºhrung des Projekt-Glossars
  • Besseres Verst√§ndnis f√ºr pausierte Key-User
  • Einheitliche Sprache im Projekt
  1. Anpassung/Trennung der einzelnen Umfragen
  • Wave-bezogene Umfragen
  • Angepasst an die jeweilige Projektphase
  1. Buddy-System f√ºr Key-User aus Wave 1 und 2
  • Erfahrene Key-User unterst√ºtzen neue Key-User
  • √úber Teams-Tag-Funktion organisiert
  • Austausch bleibt sichtbar f√ºr andere

Schulung und Training

Die Key-User wurden in zwei Schienen geschult: im Systembereich und vom Change Management im Bereich Trainingsgestaltung, Umgang mit Widerst√§nden und Umgang mit Endusern. Die Schulungsunterlagen waren Aufgabe der Key-User, wurden aber von den DPOs reviewed. Enduser wurden einbezogen, um zu pr√ºfen, ob das Level f√ºr gute Schulungen erreicht wurde.

Die Enduser-Trainings werden von den Key-Usern geplant und durchgef√ºhrt. Die Key-User stehen nach dem Go-Live als Hypercare-Support zur Verf√ºgung und sind danach erste Ansprechpartner f√ºr die Enduser. Die Trainingsunterlagen werden auf einer Enduser-SharePoint-Seite f√ºr alle zug√§nglich abgelegt und sind √ºber SAP Enable Now nachtr√§glich verf√ºgbar.

Bei der Trainingsplanung durften die Key-User die Gruppengr√∂√üe selbst festlegen, was zu mehr Wohlbefinden f√ºhrte. Es wurden Dry Runs veranstaltet, bei denen die Key-User ihre Classroom-Trainings vor dem Projektteam vorf√ºhren und Feedback erhalten konnten. Templates wurden bereitgestellt, um die Key-User zu entlasten.

Rolle des Change Managements

Das Change Management wurde erst mit diesem Projekt aufgebaut. Intern lastet die Arbeit auf einer Person (=Kathleen), unterst√ºtzt von drei Personen eines Implementierungspartners. Ein Community Lead aus den Key-Usern war geplant, konnte aber aufgrund von Zeitmangel nicht umgesetzt werden. Das Change Management √ºbernahm daher wieder die Moderation.

Die Kommunikation an das Management war wichtig, um sicherzustellen, dass die Key-User Zeit f√ºr ihre Projektarbeit bekommen und nicht mit 150 Prozent belastet werden. Das Change Management nutzte SAP Enable Now f√ºr die Erstellung von Lernpfaden f√ºr neue Kollegen um das Onboarding optimal vorzubereiten.

Erkenntnisse aus der Diskussion in der Community Session

Die Teilnehmenden an der Session teilten zahlreiche eigene Erfahrungen. H√§ufig genannte Herausforderungen waren √úberlastung der Key-User, Sprachbarrieren, regionale Arbeitsweisen, uneinheitliche Anforderungen und fehlende Ressourcen.

Was funktioniert in der Praxis?

Formate f√ºr erfolgreiche Communities:

  • Pr√§senztreffen und direkter Austausch
  • Zwei Stunden Treffen alle zwei Wochen mit der Projektleitung
  • Zweimal monatlich eine Stunde via Teams
  • Subgruppen nach Lokationen
  • Regelm√§√üige Calls mit fester Agenda
  • Moderierte Online-Plattformen
  • Informelle Treffen wie Kaffeeroulette

Unterst√ºtzungsma√ünahmen:

  • Train-the-Trainer-Seminare
  • Change-Management-Trainings
  • Konfliktmanagement-Training
  • Ambassador-Netzwerke
  • Templates f√ºr Schulungsunterlagen
  • Dry Runs mit Feedback
  • Tandem-Ans√§tze bei ersten Schulungen
  • Zus√§tzliche Testressourcen

Engagement f√∂rdern ‚Äì denn Engagement ist eine der gro√üen Herausforderungen in Communities:

  • Niedrigschwellige Formate wie Polls
  • Belohnungen f√ºr Key-User wie Special Events
  • In manchen F√§llen monet√§re Anreize
  • Lessons-Learned-Sessions
  • Gemeinsame Retrospektiven
  • Social Events ‚Äì feiern von Erfolgen

Innovative Ans√§tze:

  • Kaffeeroulette √ºber Teams: Zwei bis drei User werden per Zufall f√ºr eine Viertelstunde zusammengef√ºhrt
  • Networking Lunch mit Matching nach Interessen
  • Themenvorschl√§ge f√ºr informelle Treffen

Konkrete Tipps f√ºr die Praxis von Key-User Netzwerken

Auch wenn es nun evtl. Dopplungen gibt versuche ich hier nochmals Tips von Kathleen sowie den vielen Community Teilnehmenden hier aufzuf√ºhren. 

Timing und Planung

Timing beachten: Den richtigen Zeitpunkt f√ºr den Community-Start w√§hlen. Key-User brauchen etwas Greifbares, um sich beteiligen zu k√∂nnen.

Einheitliches Onboarding: Alle Key-User-Gruppen von Anfang an gleich abholen, um unterschiedliche Wissensst√§nde zu vermeiden.

Wave-bezogene Planung: Umfragen und Meetings an die jeweilige Projektphase anpassen.

Kommunikation und Moderation

Aktive Moderation: Communities brauchen aktive Moderation und regelm√§√üige Impulse. Communication Starter allein reichen nicht.

Kommunikationsfrequenz erh√∂hen: Zwei bis drei Impulse pro Woche setzen, um Bewegung in die Community zu bringen.

Management einbinden: F√ºhrungskr√§fte √ºber den Zeitbedarf der Key-User informieren.

Sprache und Verst√§ndnis

Sprache anpassen: Bei internationalen Projekten Meetings und Unterlagen in Landessprache anbieten.

Technische Hilfsmittel nutzen: MS Teams mit Co-Pilot und Teams Professional f√ºr √úbersetzungen nutzen.

Glossar erstellen: Sicherstellen, dass alle in einer Sprache sprechen durch ein Projekt-Glossar.

Entlastung und Unterst√ºtzung

Entlastung schaffen: Key-User durch Templates, Dry Runs, Tandem-Ans√§tze und zus√§tzliche Ressourcen (z.B. beim Testen) aktiv unterst√ºtzen.

Didaktische Unterst√ºtzung: Power User oder Autoren unterst√ºtzen bei der Unterlagenerstellung.

Backfill organisieren: Neue Mitarbeitende einstellen oder interne Umverteilung f√ºr Daily Business.

Formate und Tools

Pr√§senz erm√∂glichen: Wo m√∂glich, Pr√§senztreffen oder zumindest regelm√§√üige Online-Meetings mit fester Agenda organisieren.

Buddy-Systeme nutzen: Erfahrene Key-User mit neuen Key-Usern vernetzen.

Tool-Wahl: Abh√§ngig von Kommunikationsgewohnheiten im Unternehmen (Teams, Slack, SharePoint).

Subgruppen bilden: Nach Lokationen, Workstreams oder Waves organisieren.

Erwartungsmanagement

Erwartungen managen: Nicht erwarten, dass alle aktiv mitmachen. In Communities sind oft nur ein bis zwei Prozent wirklich aktiv.

Publikum vs. Community: Verstehen, dass Community-Bildung Zeit braucht.

Zusammenfassung

Der Aufbau einer Key-User-Community in einem internationalen S/4HANA-Projekt ist komplex und braucht Zeit. Die initiale Infrastruktur allein reicht nicht aus. Key-User befinden sich in einer Doppelrolle zwischen Daily Business und Projekt und brauchen aktive Unterst√ºtzung, klare Strukturen und das Gef√ºhl, nicht allein zu sein.

Entscheidend ist, Key-User nicht zu √ºberfordern, sondern durch Templates, Schulungen und Tandem-Ans√§tze zu entlasten. Sprachbarrieren und unterschiedliche Wissensst√§nde sollten aktiv adressiert werden. Der richtige Zeitpunkt f√ºr den Community-Start ist wichtig. Key-User brauchen etwas Konkretes, um sich beteiligen zu k√∂nnen.

Die Anpassungen in Wave 2 zeigten Wirkung: einheitliches Onboarding, h√∂here Kommunikationsfrequenz, Meetings in Landessprache, Buddy-Systeme und die Einbindung der DPOs und TPOs.

Change Management ist kein Nice-to-have, sondern essenziell f√ºr den Projekterfolg. Die Erkenntnis, dass viele Herausforderungen trotz unterschiedlicher Branchen √§hnlich sind, zeigt uns auch wieder den Wert des Austauschs in der Community.

Weiterf√ºhrende Links und Ressourcen

SAP Community

  • SAP Training and Change Management Community
  • Dokumentation der Kaffee-Ecke Sessions und n√§chster Termin

Kommende Sessions

  • Walk Me Praxisbeispiel - Webinar mit Stada (12/2025) / Walk Me Learning Arc - Infosession zur Learning Komponente (Januar 2026) / Enable Now zu Walk Me Transition - Roundtable (Februar 2026) ‚Äì Infos und Anmeldung hier
  • Kaffee-Ecke ‚Äì Change & Training Retrospektive 2025/ Ausblick 2026 - 18.12.2025

√úber die Kaffee-Ecke: Die SAP Training and Change Management Kaffee-Ecke ist eine monatliche Community Session, die jeden dritten Donnerstag im Monat stattfindet. Sie bietet Raum f√ºr Austausch, Good Practices und Lessons Learned rund um Training, Learning und Change Management in SAP-Projekten.

Bei Interesse an einem Impuls in kommenden Sessions oder Fragen zur Community meldet Euch gerne.

entry.title: BP user exits to check data before saving (SAP GUI transaction for Business Partners)
entry.content:
I've read a few questions and answers about which user exit to choose to add custom checks before saving in the SAP GUI transaction BP (maintenance of business partners), but without understanding which ones to choose, how they are all related, what they exactly do. I'm trying here to provide an overview of what I have quickly understood.

I'm running S/4HANA 2023 FPS 1 (ABAP 7.58 SP 1).

In short, there are these user exits, called sequentially:

  • the BP checks by the BDT framework (Business Data Toolset),
  • the BP checks by the BAdI BUPA_FURTHER_CHECKS,
  • the vendor or customer specific checks by the BAdI VENDOR_EXTENSION_CHECK and CUSTOMER_EXTENSION_CHECK.
  • NB: if I understand well, S/4HANA has merged customer and vendor maintenance into BP, and before S/4HANA, there were specific vendor and customer user exits (not part of BP) which were the Business Transaction Events 1340 and 1440 and the BAdI CUSTOMER_ADD_DATA and VENDOR_ADD_DATA, method CHECK_ALL_DATA. I don't discuss them here.

In BP, the BDT checks are first called. You may create your own function module (no parameters) and add it to the transaction code BUS7 for the event DCHCK. For the sequence number, you may enter any two last characters (positions 6 and 7) other than "00" (double zero), because the positions are reserved for custom use, as explained in the SAP Help Portal:

  • Naming convention: The position number has 7 places. Each development stage has one place of its own. The places from the left up to your own place are freely assignable. The application uses them to determine the position of the view within a section in relation to the views of the upstream development stages. The numbers to the right of your own place must be ‚Äò0‚Äô.
  • The following places are reserved for the development stages:
  • Application basis 1+2
  • Standard applications 3
  • Industry applications 4
  • Development partners 5
  • Customers (central) 6
  • Customers (branch) 7

Then, the method CHECK_CENTRAL of the Classic BAdI BUPA_FURTHER_CHECKS is called. You may also implement it (transaction code SE18, menu Implementations > Create). This method receives few parameters (table BUT000, name, organization data, person data). If you need other data from the business partner, you may call function modules like BUP_BUPA_BUT0IS_GET (table BUT0IS being the industry sectors defined at the BP level) to get the data modified (or not) by the user, before the data is really saved to the database.

After that, if the partner is of type vendor, BP calls the method CHECK of the BAdI Definition VENDOR_EXTENSION_CHECK of the Enhancement Spot VENDOR_EXTENSION.

If the partner of type customer, BP calls the method CHECK of the BAdI Definition CUSTOMER_EXTENSION_CHECK of the Enhancement Spot CUSTOMER_EXTENSION.

The two BAdI above receive only the vendor or customer specific data, not the whole business partner data, to prevent saving the data to the vendor or customer specific tables LFA1, KNA1 (and so on), but even if an error is raised by the user exit, the business partner data is saved.

In my case, I wanted to define a blocking check on BP data, the most simple way, so I used the classic BAdI BUPA_FURTHER_CHECKS.

For information, if you want to know about how the vendor or customer specific data is filtered out from the business partner data, it's done by the class CVI_STRATEGY_BP_VENDOR, in the method IF_MDS_CTRL_STRATEGY_IMPL~PROCESS.

I don't know how exactly the BP customizing decides how to display the vendor or customer data, and how it's saved into the tables LFA1, KNA1, etc. What I could understand:

  1. If you create a Business Partner, you choose a partner group from the table TB000 (e.g. PCUS, PVEN)
  2. The SPRO activity "Define partner role from client to partner" (SM30 > CVIV_CUST_TO_BP2) assigns one or more partner roles (e.g. FLCU00) to the partner group (e.g. PCUS).
  3. The SPRO activity "Define partner role from vendor to partner" (SM30 > CVIV_VEND_TO_BP2) assigns one or more partner roles (e.g. FLVN00) to a partner group (e.g. PVEN).
  4. The SPRO activity "Define partner roles" (SM34 > BUPA_TB003) links the partner role (e.g. FLCU00) to the BDT partner view (e.g. FLCU00). This BDT partner view is defined in the transaction BUSD and is connected to Dynpro screens with ABAP logic. It's not clear to me how, from here, some BDT partner function modules are called at save time and how they write to either the table LFA1 (vendor) or KNA1 (customer).
  5. The SPRO activity "Assign partner role to client group" (V_TBD001) assigns a client group from KNA1-KTOKD (e.g. CUST) to a partner group (e.g. PCUS). This customizing indicates if the client number is the same as the partner number. For information, the relationship table is CVI_CUST_LINK.
  6. The SPRO activity "Assign partner role to vendor group" (V_TBC001) assigns a vendor group from LFA1-KTOKK (e.g. VEND) to a partner group (e.g. PVEN). This customizing indicates if the vendor number is the same as the partner number. For information, the relationship table is CVI_VEND_LINK.

If I've missed something, if I'm wrong or if you can enlighten me, please add a comment. I will then update this post.

Thank you for reading!

entry.title: How AI Solutions Can Align with SAP‚Äôs Clean Core Principles
entry.content:
‚ÄúClean core‚Äù and ‚ÄúArtificial Intelligence‚Äù are often discussed in isolation. Clean core is positioned to reduce technical debt and keep SAP S/4HANA upgradeable, while AI is usually associated with new workloads, additional components, and non-SAP technologies such as Python.

This separation leads to a common misconception: that AI solutions, especially those implemented in Python or using external models, are incompatible with a clean core strategy.

In practice, AI and clean core are closely aligned. SAP‚Äôs own definition of an ERP clean core emphasizes standardization, modern extensibility, and the ability to leverage reliable data and AI innovations on top of a stable core. When designed correctly, AI solutions can fully comply with clean core principles and in many cases help to realize the intended benefits of the strategy.

SAP Clean Core Strategy

SAP describes an ERP clean core strategy as a set of guiding principles to keep business critical systems agile, cost-effective, and ready to adopt innovation. Key elements include:

  • Reduction of historically grown complexity and custom code in the core ERP system.
  • Standardization of processes by staying close to SAP best practices.
  • Use of modern extensibility options, particularly side-by-side extensions on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).
  • API- first and event-driven integration, rather than direct database access.
  • Cloud readiness and continuous innovation, including the ability to exploit AI capabilities.

Clean core does not prohibit custom logic or non-ABAP technology. It defines where that logic should run (outside the S/4 core) and how it should integrate (through released, supported interfaces).

Principles Relevant for AI Solutions

For AI initiatives, the following clean core principles are particularly relevant:

  • Decoupled innovation: AI workloads should run outside the S/4HANA core, typically on SAP BTP, and consume data via published APIs or data services.
  • Use of official extensibility models: Extensions should follow the models described in SAP‚Äôs clean core and extensibility guidance, including in-app extensions, developer extensibility (ABAP Cloud), and side-by-side extensions.
  • API-first and event-driven patterns: AI components should use official APIs and events to interact with core applications, rather than relying on direct table access or modifications.
  • Governed data access: Data for AI models should be accessed through governed layers such as SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere, which preserve security, compliance and lineage.

If an AI architecture respects these principles, it is aligned with the clean core strategy, regardless of the programming language or specific AI framework used.

Clean-Core Compliant AI Architecture Patterns

Side-by-Side AI on SAP BTP

SAP‚Äôs ‚ÄúGenerative AI on SAP BTP‚Äù reference architecture explicitly positions SAP BTP as the platform for AI workloads, with S/4HANA and other SAP cloud solutions used as systems of record.

In a side-by-side pattern:

  • SAP S/4HANA
    • Hosts standard business processes and transactional data.
    • Exposes business functionality via released OData/REST APIs and events.
  • SAP BTP (AI and application layer)
    • Runs AI workloads using SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad, where models and pipelines can be implemented in Python or other languages.
    • Uses SAP Generative AI Hub for LLM access, prompt orchestration, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and agentic scenarios.
  • Integration
    • Uses SAP Integration Suite, API Management and/or Event Mesh to connect AI components with S/4HANA through supported interfaces.

 

                       

AI workloads remain in the BTP extension layer, while SAP S/4HANA stays as the clean, standard core accessed via published APIs.

This pattern adheres to clean core because all custom AI logic and orchestration stay outside the S/4HANA core, while S/4HANA is accessed only via documented integration points.

AI Enabled Data Layer with SAP HANA Cloud

SAP has started using the term ‚ÄúAI enabled clean core with SAP HANA Cloud‚Äù, referring to architectures where S/4HANA remains the core ERP and SAP HANA Cloud provides an intelligent data layer for analytics and AI-driven applications.

Key characteristics:

  • Operational data is exposed or replicated from S/4HANA to SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere in a governed way.
  • AI models (classical ML or generative) are trained and executed against this data layer.
  • AI outputs are surfaced in side-by-side applications or written back into S/4HANA via APIs and standard extension points.

The core ERP remains clean and standard. AI driven logic is implemented in the surrounding data and application layers, which aligns with SAP‚Äôs stated goal of ‚Äúincreasing the pace of innovation and leveraging business value through reliable data and AI innovations‚Äù without compromising the core.

Programming Language and Clean Core Compliance

A frequent objection is that AI solutions are implemented in Python or with non-SAP frameworks and therefore cannot be reconciled with clean core.

From SAP‚Äôs standpoint, this is not correct. The clean core strategy focuses on minimizing custom code inside the core and using side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP to build new applications and innovations.

SAP‚Äôs own extensibility guidance explicitly acknowledges BTP side-by-side extensions implemented in ABAP Cloud, Java, Node.js and other languages. AI services developed in Python and deployed on SAP AI Core or container runtimes on BTP fall into exactly the same category.

Clean core compliance therefore depends on:

  • The location of the code (outside S/4HANA vs. in-core modifications).
  • The integration pattern (released APIs and events vs. direct table access).

It does not depend on whether the AI logic is written in ABAP, Python, Java or another language.

 

                                    

AI solutions built on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud surrounding a clean SAP S/4HANA core, with integration strictly via APIs and events.

 

SAP‚Äôs clean core strategy is often misunderstood as a constraint on innovation. It provides the architectural discipline required to adopt AI at scale without compromising the stability and upgradeability of SAP S/4HANA.

By:

  • keeping AI workloads on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud,
  • integrating through released APIs and events, and
  • applying SAP‚Äôs extensibility guidance consistently,

organizations can build advanced AI solutions that are fully aligned with clean core principles. The question is not whether AI is compatible with clean core, but whether AI architectures are designed to follow the same patterns that SAP itself recommends for any modern extension.

SAP AI Core SAP S/4HANA SAP HANA Cloud SAP Business Technology Platform SAP Event Mesh

entry.title: The Next Level of Global Payments: SAP Unlocks Enhanced Cross-Border Capabilities with TransferMate
entry.content:
In an increasingly interconnected global economy, businesses need payment solutions that are fast, transparent, secure, and seamlessly integrated into their ERP systems. That‚Äôs why the newly announced partnership between SAP and TransferMate represents a major step forward for finance and treasury teams.

Through this partnership, TransferMate‚Äôs cross-border payment service is now integrated directly into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity as a non-bank payments provider bringing powerful and innovative global payment capabilities straight into SAP ERP solutions, including SAP Cloud ERP.

For organizations operating across multiple currencies and jurisdictions, this integration has the potential to significantly simplify international financial operations.

Traditionally, making international payments required organizations to juggle multiple banking partners, external platforms, or third-party portals. This fragmented processes introduced friction, increased operational risk, and added unnecessary costs that this partnership can solve

What You Can Expect from TransferMate‚Äôs integration into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity

- Fast, transparent and efficient international payments without leaving your ERP

  • No additional portals or manual steps; enjoy seamless straight-through processing.
  • Automated flows from SAP ERP directly to TransferMate payment infrastructure reducing errors, manual intervention, and operational risk.

- Reduced complexity and improved scalability

  • SAP users can send and receive funds globally through a the unified and standardized payment infrastructure from TransferMate.
  • A scalable payment solution that grows with organizations expanding their international footprint.

- Greater transparency and control

  • End-to-end visibility from cross border payment initiation to settlement
  • Enhanced liquidity management with better payment tracking and more payment options.

- Strengthened compliance and security

  • TransferMate operates a fully regulated global payments network, ensuring adherence to local and international financial regulations.

Who Can Benefit?

Any organization using SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity‚Äîregardless of whether they are running SAP ERP, SAP S/4HANA, or SAP Cloud ERP‚Äîcan take advantage of this integration.

As companies continue to expand globally, the demand for frictionless, embedded financial tools will only grow. The integration of TransferMate into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity marks a major step toward making global payments as simple, secure, and seamless as domestic transactions‚Äîdirectly from your SAP environment.

Want to Know More?

SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity

  • https://www.sap.com/germany/products/financial-management/multi-bank-connectivity.html
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_MULTI_BANK_CONNECTIVITY

TransferMate

  • https://www.transfermate.com/
  • TransferMate Press Release

entry.title: S/4HANA 2023 FPS3 Fully-Activated Appliance standard installation
entry.content:
This blog covers installation of (1) SAP S/4HANA server and (2) SAP NW JAVA / ADS server as shown in the graphic below. The installation is based on file restore and is different from the standard installs using SWPM.

Please refer to S/4HANA SQUARE ONE for other blogs

In this blog the procedure is simplified for standard installation with NO HOSTNAME OR SID CHANGE. The advantage with this is that you don't have to do many of the steps related to SID change and it does make sense if you will be installing the instance temporarily. If your network cannot accommodate the unique hostname and SID and If you want to change hostname and sid please refer to other blog. Also if it is a more permanent installation you may like to change SID and hostname.

This Blog is based on a fresh installation of SUSE Linux for SAP OS without having any previous SAP instances created and deleted. I did not have to pre install hostagent, etc. There are mount points/links to be setup as shown in the right place in the directory structure. The steps in the guides provided with SAP Note 2041140 could be used as a reference in case there are issues specific to your environment. Just follow the steps below to install both systems shown in red square below:

Please find below the main note for ordering the appliance:
2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

PART1: SOFTWARE DOWNLOAD

Please download the software media from https://me.sap.com/softwarecenter
INSTALLATIONS & UPGRADES => By Alphabetical Index (A-Z) => S => SAP S/4HANA => SAP S/4HANA 2023 => S/4HANA FULLY-ACTIVATED APPLIANCE => SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 FA APPL

On SAP S/4HANA Server, download the 51058694_1 to 51058694_5  files and SWPM20SP22_3-80003424.SAR (or later).

On SAP NW JAVA / ADS server, download the 51058694_5, SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR and 51050829_JAVA_part 1 & 2 - NW 7.5 Java based SW Comp.

PART2: INSTALL SAP S/4HANA

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. For /sapmnt provide min 30GB, /hana/data space - min 500GB, /hana/log min 120GB. I have used /sapmedia - 200GB temporary separate mount that can be removed later.

TIP: The /sapmedia filesystem could be external mount. To save this space, the files could be downloaded to /hana/data/HDB and deleted as they are being extracted. In this case it would be good to extract dbdata files first.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below:

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES Extract files 51058694_*  in /sapmedia

sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_1.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_2.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_3.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_4.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_5.ZIP

Allow approx 2 hours for extraction.

We will install Central system with DB and App on same server. Please move all *.tgz-* files (from 51058694_1 to 51058694_4) to /sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1

cd /sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
mv /sapmedia/51058694_2/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_2/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_3/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_3/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_4/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_4/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_5/*.tgz-*   .

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

Please use command below to extract the database related archives:

sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia/# cd 51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
cat dblog.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

Similarly extract the remaining files:

cat dbexe.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

It takes about an hour for extraction.

Below two Application related archives may be extracted on a separate app server for distributed installation. These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/S4H and /usr/sap/S4H

Then extract the files:
sid-hdb-s4h:/usr/sap #cd 51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
cat sapmnt_s4h.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
cat usrsap_s4h.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml

STEP 4: REGISTER DATABASE 

Follow this procedure as it is a known issue, please refer SAP Note 2082466 - Known Issues in SAP HANA Platform Lifecycle Management (HDBLCM)  (Issue# 69)

cd /hana/shared/HDB/HDB02/vhcalhdbdb
rm .daemon.ini.swp

vi daemon.ini
Edit section [localsecurestore] to change instances = 0

Execute HANA database specific steps as below:

sid-hdb-s4h: ##/hana/shared/HDB/hdblcm/hdblcm --action=register_rename_system

This should bring up the database processes as below

sid-hdb-s4h: #/usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 02 -function GetProcessList

STEP 5: EXTRACT SWPM Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-hdb-s4h:/install ##/sapmnt/S4H/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM20SP22_3-80003424.SA

STEP 6:RENAME SAP SYSTEM Rename instance using sapinst, although we want to keep SID same as standard - S4H we need to run the procedure so that the process installs the missing items.

sid-hdb-s4h:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_ENFORCE_CRL=false SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcals4hci 

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:
https://sid-hdb-s4h.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST above screen select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At above screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System S4H and Target System S4H:
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen SAP HANA Database Connectivity enter Instance Number 02 and Password Welcome_2Welocme_2. Click on Next.

At the screen SAP HANA Database Parameter you can change Schema User , DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM password. Please note it is also optional to change the schema user SAPHANADB password along with DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM users.

At the screen Database Schema accept schema SAPHANADB password and confirm Schema password Xxxxxxxn click on Next.

At the screen Rename Tenant Database click on Next

At the screen Secure Storage for Database Connection select HANA Secure User tore (hdbuserstore) click on Next

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn

At the screen Secure Storage Key Generation accept radio button ‚Äì Individual Key (Recommended for Productive Systems) On the Next

At next screen Warning click OK

At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next

At the above screen Keep Existing Licenses accept unchecked of Keep existing licenses. Click on Next

At the screen Install License Key keep unchecked Install License Key. Click on Next

TIP: It is much easier to install the license by providing the file than doing it later through the application.
At next screen Cleanup of Encryption key checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

TIP: In case you get this ERROR:

RESOLUTION: Follow SAP Note 2800204 - SSFX-0362: Value file "-" does not start with the UTF-8 byte order mark

Ensure the environment variable LC_CTYPE of the user running sapinst is set as LC_CTYPE=en_US.
Stop the current sapinst and restart it. Continue with the existing option.

Then you can manually start the SAP instance S4H

sid-hdb-s4h:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 01 -function StartSystem ALL
sid-hdb-s4h:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function StartSystem ALL

After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder and remove temporary links to S4H.

Standard users are as follows:
HANA DB ‚Äì Instance 02 SYSTEM /<Master Password>
Web Dispatcher access : bpinst/Welcome_2Welcome_2

STEP 7: Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf => Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Adapt HANA connections in DBACOCKPIT

Host name / port in table HTTPURLLOC

Adapt RFC Connections if needed

ABAP connections:
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_RFC
‚Ä¢ S4HCLNT100 (and other clients)
‚Ä¢ S4H_RFC

HTTP connections:
‚Ä¢ ADS (pointing to the JAVA server after PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA /ADS)
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_HTTP
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_HTTPS
‚Ä¢ S4FIN_HTTPS

SAP Enable Now Web Assistant

Adapt the Fiori notification URL

Adapt Enterprise Search

Apply product license keys

Install software product license key: Technical restrictions may apply if you don‚Äôt install the license. Use the link to obtain license key.
HANA DB license key can be installed via HANA Studio (Preferences -> License)
From SAP S/4HANA 1909 onwards the license key is installed via SAP logon tCode SLICENSE

Further post-installation checks

Install SAP client tools on your local computers

You can take a full backup and remove the temporary links that were setup for S4H

In client 000 fix transport configuration. Enter tCode SE06 and reinstall CTS transport system.

Adapt any SAP parameters required

The database is provided with log mode overwrite and you may like to change that as needed.

PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA / ADS

STEP 1: Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. Total filesystem needed is min 70GB for installation.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below:

STEP 2: Extract files 51058694_5.ZIP  in /sapmedia

sid-j2e:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_5.ZIP

We will install Java instance from files in  /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

cd /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/J2E

sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat dblog.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat dbexe.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat sapmnt_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat usrsap_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml

STEP 4: Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-j2e:/install #/sapmnt/J2E/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR

STEP 5: Rename instance using sapinst

sid-j2e:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_ENFORCE_CRL=false SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcalj2eci SAPINST_SLP_MODE=false

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-j2e.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At the screen Software Integrity click on Next

At screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System J2E
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen Database System Type keep the default selection SAP Adaptive Server Enterprise for Business Suite

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn

At the screen Operating System User for SAP Database Administrator enter the password for sybj2e and User ID and Click on Next

At the screen SAP ASE Database System Parameters accept or change ports and Click on Next

At the screen Database User Passwords enter the passwords for user sa, sapsa, sapsso, SAPSR3DB which is Welcome_2Welcome_2. Click on Next

At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next
At the screen Install License Key keep unchecked Install License Key. Click on Next

TIP: It is much easier to install the license by providing the file than doing it later through the application.

At next screen Cleanup of Operating System Users checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next

Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

 

You can manually start/stop the SAP Java instance J2E using old commands

sid-j2e:/install # su - j2eadm
sid-j2e:j2eadm > startsap

To access JAVA server as SAP Netweaver Adminstrator the URL is:
https://sid-j2e.dummy.nodomain:50000/nwa

Standard users are as follows:

JAVA Administrator ‚Äì Administrator / <Master Password> ;
Java user BPINST/Welcome2Welcome2

STEP 6: Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf - Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Apply product license keys if you haven't installed during swpm install step before. Technical restrictions may apply if you don‚Äôt install the license. Use the link to obtain license key. SAPNetweaver 7.5 J2EE license key has to be installed via SAP Netweaver Administrator

Further post-installation checks

Adapt any SAP parameters due to changed SID

After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder.

SUPPORT TICKETS:

If you have any difficulty downloading the media open OSS message using component XX-SER-SAPSMP-SWC. If you have issues with technical deployment open message with component BC-INS-SRN.
