Thank you. Hope you enjoyed the installation.

Mahesh Sardesai
Product Expert ‚Äì S/4HANA

entry.title: How to Assign Item Category to Material While Syncing to SAP CPQ ‚Äì And Why It Matters
entry.content:
When integrating SAP CPQ (Configure, Price, Quote) with SAP S/4HANA or ERP, ECC, one critical step often overlooked is assigning the Item Category to materials during synchronization. This seemingly small detail plays a major role in ensuring smooth downstream processes like Sales Orders, Solution Quotations, and Solution Orders.

What is an Item Category ?

An Item Category in SAP determines how a material behaves in a document. It controls:

  • Whether the item is relevant for pricing.
  • If it requires a delivery or billing.
  • Whether it‚Äôs a service, a configurable product, or a standard material.
  • How it integrates with BOMs or solution components.

Reference Article/Blog explaining Item Categeory & group : Link

In short, the Item Category defines the business logic for the material in transactional documents.

Why Assign Item Category During Sync to SAP CPQ?

When materials are synced from SAP ERP to SAP CPQ, they carry essential attributes like material number, description, and pricing conditions. However, without the correct Item Category, CPQ cannot:

  • Determine if the material is a physical product, service, or text item.
  • Apply correct pricing and tax rules.
  • Generate accurate solution structures for complex configurations.

This impacts the integration when below are created:

  • Sales Orders: Applies for all ERP, S/4 HANA Public & Private Cloud
  • Solution Quotations: S/4 HANA Private Cloud or On-prem versions (Sales, Service & Subscription)
  • Solution Orders: S/4 HANA Public Cloud Edition (Sales, Service & Subscription)

Integration with SAP CPQ for Material Replication

SAP CPQ provides Product RestAPI to update itemcategorygroup for Materials..

Technical Note: Updating Item Category in SAP CPQ

SAP CPQ provides a Product REST API that allows you to update the itemCategory field for products. This is useful when you need to dynamically adjust item categories after initial synchronization or based on business rules.

  • Field: itemCategory
  • Purpose: Stores the ERP item category value or a mapped equivalent.
  • Usage: Can be updated via REST API calls for products in CPQ.

Integration Considerations

The standard SAP CPQ‚ÄìSAP ERP/S4 HANA integration iFlow currently uses SOAP XML for material synchronization. This means:

  • Item category values from ERP cannot be included in the SOAP payload. (Help Doc)
  • If additional updates are needed post-sync, you can leverage the REST API for CPQ to patch the itemCategory field.

Conclusion:
Assigning the right Item Category during material sync to SAP CPQ is not just a technical step‚Äîit‚Äôs a business-critical process that ensures seamless integration, accurate pricing, and smooth execution of sales and solution orders.

entry.title: Article Discontinuation
entry.content:
Article Discontinuation ‚Äì Business and Technical Overview

Article Discontinuation is a key step in an article‚Äôs lifecycle when the business decides that the product should no longer be carried. This decision can stem from several business scenarios, including:

Business Reasons for Article Discontinuation

  • Seasonal Fashion Items: Style cycles end and new season assortments are introduced.
  • End-of-Life Packaging Changes: Example: shifting from plastic bottles to eco-friendly recyclable packaging.
  • Model Upgrades in Electronics: Regular product refresh cycles.
  • Poor Sales Performance: Example: a slow-moving cereal brand removed by a grocery retailer.
  • Vendor Stops Supplying the Product.
  • Regulatory or Compliance Restrictions.
  • Short Shelf-Life or Expiry Constraints.
  • Assortment Rationalization / Space Optimization.
  • Product Safety Recalls.

Additionally, there are cases where an article is initially listed broadly for simplicity, but this creates technical issues later. In SAP Retail, listing is driven by general assortments, assortment modules, and listing conditions, and articles should only appear in sites belonging to their intended assortments. Incorrect assignments can cause unwanted listing propagation.

Business Impact of Incorrect Listing

  • Inaccurate stock availability displayed to store teams and online channels.
  • Unnecessary MRP proposals generated for all sites.
  • Incorrect data distributed to POS systems, causing clutter and possible cashier confusion.
  • Merchandising teams receive inaccurate assortment compliance reports.

Technical Impact

  • Unintended listing entries created in WLK1.
  • Additional footprints generated in tables such as MVKE, MARC, MBEW, etc.
  • POS outbound IDocs (WP_PLU) triggered for all sites.
  • Increased load on replenishment processing and EDI queues.
  • Incorrect inherited listing indicators in WRS1.
  • Business processes such as costing process unnecessary data, potentially affecting performance and increasing system footprint.

 Delisting vs. Discontinuation

Delisting (Removing Listing Conditions)

Delisting stops an article from being processed but does not remove the article master footprint.

Transaction codes for delisting:

  • WSP3 ‚Äì Delete individual article listing conditions per distribution chain
  • WSE6 ‚Äì Delete listing per assortment
  • Removing a site from an assortment using WSOA6 automatically delists all articles belonging to that site/assortment combination.

System behavior when an article is delisted:

  • Listing conditions are deleted automatically.
  • All listing entries (WLK1, WRS1, etc.) created through that assortment/module are removed.
  • The article master remains intact (MARA, MARC, MARD not deleted).
  • Existing stock remains visible and sellable.
  • MRP and procurement are blocked‚Äîno new POs/STOs will be created.
  • Sales may continue until on-hand stock reaches zero.

Article Discontinuation (Removing the Article Footprint)

To eliminate an article from the system, the process involves:

  1. Discontinuation ‚Äì Sets the deletion indicator (LVORM)
  2. Archiving and Deletion ‚Äì Executed via SARA (Object: MM_MATNR)

Discontinuation has far greater impact than delisting. When an article is discontinued:

  • The article master and all related data (purchasing info records, listing data, etc.) are marked for removal and eventually deleted through archiving.

Levels of Discontinuation

  • Client-wide
  • Supplier/Vendor
  • Plant/Site (includes distribution chain level)

Article Discontinuation Process in SAP Retail

  1. End listing conditions for the article using WSP3/WSE6/WSOA6.
  2. Trigger discontinuation using WRF_DIS_SEL (and monitor via WRF_DIS_MON).
  3. The discontinuation runs based on the Article Discontinuation Date‚Äîthis must be after the ordering or sales block date.
  4. To run in background:
    • Deselect ‚ÄúCheck material in full‚Äù
    • Select ‚ÄúOffline checks‚Äù

  1. Review the worklist in WRF_DIS_MON after job completion.
  2. If ‚ÄúDiscontinue Immediately‚Äù is enabled and checks pass, SAP sets the deletion flag automatically.
  3. If issues exist, SAP lists them for manual resolution.
  4. Optional automated follow-up actions (e.g., transfer posting stock to a value-only article).
  5. Configuration: SPRO ‚Üí Logistics General ‚Üí Material Master ‚Üí Retail Specific Settings ‚Üí Settings for Material Discontinuation
  6. Once LVORM is set ‚Üí Archive and delete via SARA (MM_MATNR).

Useful Information & Tools

Set deletion flags at Sales Org/Distribution Channel level

Use standard report RWSORT41MVKE
Key fields:

  • AUF_SAM: Explode generic material
  • P_TEST: Test mode
  • S_MATKL: Article Group
  • S_MATNR: Article
  • S_VKORG: Sales Organization
  • S_VTWEG: Distribution Channel

Mass Discontinuation for All Articles at a Site

  • Enter wildcard (*) for article in WRF_DIS_SEL
  • Enter target plant/site under Plant Data
  • Note: This selects all MARC records for that site‚Äîevaluate volume before execution.

Reset Deletion Flag

Use WSE8

Important Limitations

  • Discontinuation indicators in MARA/MARC cannot be set using BAPIs or IDocs. Only WRF_DIS_SEL supports this process.

entry.title: Introducing User-Defined Reports (UDR) in SAP Responsible Production and Design
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of SAP Responsible Design and Production (RDP) as of November 25, 2025.

SAP Responsible Design and Production (RDP) released User-Defined Reports (UDR) this year, extending its reporting framework with a fully configurable, customer-driven approach developed to support customers with the ever-evolving and growing number of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) regulations. With UDR, users can now create customized EPR reports for packaging based on their unique business and compliance needs.

UDR also enables SAP and in the near future, content partners, to offer templates for new EPR schemes that customers can adapt in their own systems, to help them expand EPR reporting quickly. This new functionality aims to ease the burden of managing reporting obligations across multiple markets.

This blog post explains the background and motivation for this feature, provides a sneak peek into the key functionalities used to create country-specific EPR report categories, and highlights how this enhancement improves flexibility and extensibility for EPR data reporting.

Background

As EPR regulations continue to expand globally, businesses face increasing complexity in how they manage compliance. Regulations vary not only from country to country but often overlap or undergo changes over time, making it challenging for customers to keep up while relying on predefined reporting structures.

SAP RDP has long supported customers in meeting EPR requirements through SAP-provided report categories that are preconfigured to match the packaging obligations in countries such as Spain, Italy, and the UK. While these reports have served as a reliable foundation, there is a growing need for a more flexible and more nuanced reporting approach.

Companies increasingly require a way to:

  • Adapt quickly to new or changing legislation
  • Reuse rules and fee structures across similar reporting schemes or Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs)
  • Consolidate data from diverse sources
  • Customize reporting logic based on their specific business context

This is exactly why SAP introduced User-Defined Reports (UDR): to provide customers with an agile, scalable, and future-ready foundation for building report categories aligned with regulatory logic, business context, and compliance requirements.

Key Capabilities of UDR

User-Defined Reports bring together several powerful capabilities that allow customers to design report categories tailored to their specific regulatory and operational needs. 

1 Build the Structure of Your Report

Responsible Organizations

EPR schemes are managed by Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs). Many countries operate with more than one PRO, each offering different fee structures or criteria. In Spain, for example, Ecoembes manages general packaging, while Ecovidrio is responsible for glass packaging. UDR allows users to:

  • Attach multiple PRO-specific fee tables to the same report category
  • Reuse the same report fractions and rules across PROs
  • Avoid creating separate report categories for each PRO (as long as their rules do not conflict)

This gives customers flexibility in markets where several PROs coexist.

Report Fractions

Report fractions are the foundational building blocks of a UDR report. They represent the categories into which packaging is classified according to national legislation or PRO requirements. Fractions can be created and named based on the exact fee structure of the country or PRO, ensuring a one-to-one alignment with how fees are calculated.

Report Fraction Groups

To support cleaner structuring and reporting layouts, fractions can be combined into report fraction groups. These groups help users organize related fractions (for example, separating paper-related fractions based on usage or the brand) and simplify both calculation and reporting outputs.

2 Control the Logic Behind Your Report

Filters for Included Packaging

Filters add a foundational layer of control by allowing users to exclude packaging that should not be part of a particular report or fee calculation. They can be applied at multiple levels within the report category setup and help ensure that only relevant data is included based on the requirements of each EPR scheme.

Together with calculation rules, filters help shape a reporting outcome that aligns with legislative and business requirements.

Calculation Rules

Report calculation rules form one of the most powerful elements of UDR.
They determine which packaging is included in a report and how quantities and fees are calculated, giving customers the flexibility to reflect the exact compliance logic required by each market. Because calculation rules can combine multiple conditions, attributes, and data sources, they enable users to shape reporting logic precisely around their business and regulatory needs, making this capability central to the flexibility that UDR offers.

Calculation rules come with a wide collection of rule examples, expressions and functions that can be leveraged to fit the users‚Äô reporting requirements.

Logistic Processes

Logistic processes represent the specific movements of products or packaging that are relevant for a country‚Äôs EPR legislation, such as domestic sales, imports, exports, or other flows defined by the market. In UDR, users can select which logistic processes apply to their report category and combine them with filters or calculation rules. This allows the user to reflect only the movements that are obligated in that country, ensuring the report aligns with how packaging enters or leaves the market.

 

3 Capture Sustainability-Driven Criteria

Ecomodulation

Many EPR schemes increasingly use ecomodulation to reward sustainable packaging choices. UDR allows users to set ecomodulation criteria based on the relevant EPR scheme and incorporate them into calculation rules. This further enables fees to be calculated according to the required ecomodulation rules. To learn more about ecomodulation, visit the SAP RDP community page for a detailed blog on this topic, releasing soon.

Recyclability

UDR also integrates recyclability outcomes directly into reports. When setting up a report, recyclability guidelines can be selected and applied, to be used in calculation rules when needed. This allows recyclability insights to feed directly into the report structure, supporting countries where recyclability affects fees or criteria (such as the bonus/malus payments on EPR fees in France). Users can either upload date manually via Excel or integrate with a partner of their choice.

4 Test and Validate Your Setup

Test Configuration

With test configurations, users can simulate the reporting outcome for one to ten products. This enables quick validation of rule logic, filters, and fee calculations before generating the full report, ensuring accuracy and reducing iteration time.

5 Templates

Not all EPR schemes have the same level of complexity. To ease the effort in building highly detailed report categories using UDR, Templates have been introduced; preconfigured starter packs that provide the structure and logic needed to get started, which can be adapted to fit the user‚Äôs requirements.

Currently, SAP provides Templates for US-Colorado, US-Oregon, and Denmark, with more to follow. Keep an eye on the SAP RDP Roadmap for upcoming additions.

Customer Response & Early Results

Customers who tested UDR shared strong and practical feedback, including:

‚ÄúOnly 25% of time and effort is required for using UDR compared to manual efforts.‚Äù (from consumer products company)

‚ÄúFirst we were skeptic, but now we like using UDR.‚Äù (from food processing company)

These early insights reflect the impact of a flexible, user-driven reporting approach. To see this in a real-world setting, please check out our recent webinar, Navigating EPR regulations in the United States: Act Now! where our customer shares their experience with UDR.

What‚Äôs Next

UDR was shaped with direct input from customers, and this collaboration will continue. As EPR regulations evolve, SAP will focus on enhancing UDR, improving the configuration experience, and supporting reporting needs across markets.

One of the planned enhancements is around AI-assisted features that could make it easier to create calculation rules logic and work more efficiently with UDR using natural language.

Where to Learn More and Act!

To further explore UDR, detailed documentation with practical examples and additional guidance on calculation rules  available. You can also access a guided, step-by-step walkthrough showing how to create a UDR here.  We will continue to publish updates there as UDR evolves.

For broader product information on SAP Responsible Design and Production, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What‚Äôs New section, which is updated with every new software release. 

To take the next step, you can request a demo or contact us for a consultation. For additional regulatory context and practical guidance, you may also want to download our white paper on managing EPR regulations and plastic taxes.

entry.title: The Secure Way to Migrate S/4HANA: Step-by-Step HANA Tenant Copy with SSL Encryption
entry.content:
As customers rapidly migrate S/4HANA systems to Private Cloud environments (Azure, AWS, GCP, SAP RISE), they often choose an "as-is" migration. This decouples functional upgrades from the technical move, significantly compressing project duration and minimizing the need for extensive regression testing.

While traditional methods like HANA Backup/Restore (only viable for small databases) and HANA System Replication (HSR) are common, HSR presents critical challenges in a cloud migration:

  1. Homogeneous Naming: HSR demands the same SID and Instance Number for source and target, which conflicts with new naming conventions often required on the cloud, especially in SAP RISE.
  2. Auxiliary Usage: Using the HA/DR focused HSR solution for a one-time copy complicates the reconfiguration of the target HA/DR setup after cutover.
  3. Cutover Time: Breaking replication and re-establishing HA/DR post-cutover adds additional downtime.

HANA Tenant Copy: The Migration Alternative

HANA Tenant Copy is an ECS-supported approach that addresses these HSR limitations. While operationally somewhat to HSR, it differs conceptually and is suitable for migrating systems that require a SID change on the target. It creates an isolated replica of any tenant, requiring mostly that the target HANA version is same or higher than the source.

üîêSecuring the Tenant Copy Data Transfer (SSL)

A crucial security requirement is ensuring the data transfer between source and target is secure via SSL. Most Basis teams overlook this, thinking it requires external certificates. However, we can easily achieve this using the inbuilt certificate every HANA DB already possesses. In this post, we are going to see how we can 

Pre-Requisite ‚Äì

Set-up below parameters on Source and Target Database. Also, log mode should be normal for Tenant Copy to work.

Verify the SYSTEM layer values of the following parameters in the global.ini file:

  • [communication] ssl must be set to systempki
  • [system_replication_communication] enable_ssl must be set to on

On Source DB only ‚Äì

Verify the SYSTEM layer values of the following parameters in the global.ini file:

  • [communication] listeninterface must be set to .global

(A DB restart would be required in most cases).

When establishing connectivity between the Source and Target databases, the following port ranges should be opened. If security policies are restrictive, specific ports based on the instance number can be opened instead.

Port Range

Purpose

3XXXX

Mandatory. SQL port of the HANA Index Server. Main port used by application servers and SQL clients to connect to the HANA DB.

4XXXX

Mandatory. Internal HANA communication port, used heavily for system replication (HSR) and Tenant Copy.

5XXXX

Recommended. Used by nameserver, web dispatcher‚Äìrelated connections, and certain internal HA/scale-out services. Helps hosts exchange availability and topology information.

 Step-by-Step Secure Tenant Copy Execution

Step1: Create a dummy Tenant Database (ABC) on the source system to serve as a copy template. (Note: For actual migration, use the existing S/4HANA connected database, skipping this creation step.)

Take backup of the source database so that Tenant copy can be initiated (same restriction as that of HSR)

Step 2: On the target HANA system, create a Personal Security Environment (PSE) (e.g., TenantCopy) and assign its purpose as Database Replication.

Step 3: On the source HANA system, navigate to the $SECUDIR directory and copy the content of the root certificate, which is typically named clientpki_SYSTEMDB.cer. (Important: Use the SYSTEMDB certificate, not the tenant's certificate like clientpki_ABC.cer).

Step 4: Using the copied certificate content, create a new certificate entity within the target HANA database.

Step 5 : On the target system, execute the necessary SQL query to identify and note the certificate number assigned to the new certificate created in Step 4.

Step 6 : Add the certificate identified in Step 5 to the PSE created in Step 2 on the target system.

Step 7: Verify the successful addition by querying the PSE_CERTIFICATE view on the target HANA system.

Step 8: On the target system, create a Credential for the source database, using the Source SYSTEMDB password for authentication.

Step 9: On the Target, initiate the Replica Query to copy the source tenant (ABC) to the target tenant (XYZ). (In a real scenario, you would first stop the target Application Server, drop the existing S/4HANA target DB, and then create the new tenant with the exact required target name.).

Step 10 : Monitor the replication from the Target. Replication is active when the status shows Target_Active_Status = ‚ÄúYes‚Äù. The replication is complete when the DB status in M_DATABASE changes to ACTIVE REPLICA, indicating the target is ready for finalization.

 

Step 11: On the target system, issue the Finalize Replica Query to bring the target database online. (Crucially, before executing the finalization, stop the source S/4HANA system to mark the business downtime start.)

After finalization, perform follow-up activities, including reconfiguring the HDBUSERSTORE and starting the target S/4HANA application system.

References ‚Äì

Copying and Moving Tenant Databases | SAP Help Portal

Copy or Move Tenants Within System Replication | SAP Help Portal

 

Best Regards,

Javed Alam

SAP BASIS Technical Architect

entry.title: SAP EWM Labor Management (Engineered Labor Standards)
entry.content:
SAP EWM Labor Management is designed to help warehouses gain clear visibility into how efficiently work is performed on the floor. It enables businesses to define labor standards, track planned versus actual execution times, and measure processor performance for different warehouse activities. These standards can be based on various operational parameters such as weight, quantity, product attributes, or activity type, allowing flexible modeling of real-world scenarios. The functionality also supports tracking of both direct tasks and indirect labor efforts, giving a complete picture of workforce utilization. This blog focuses on demonstrating how engineering labor standards work within SAP EWM.

Configurations

1. Activate BC Sets:

T.code: SCPR20

To enable SAP EWM Labor Management (LM) functionality, SAP provides several LM-specific BC Sets. These BC Sets deliver predefined configuration content that supports various LM capabilities such as activity definitions, engineered labor standards, exception codes, performance measurement, and warehouse-level settings.

  • /SCWM/LM
  • /SCWM/LM_ACTIVITY
  • /SCWM/LM_ELS
  • /SCWM/LM_EXCEPTION_CODES
  • /SCWM/LM_EXTERNAL_PROCESS_STEPS
  • /SCWM/LM_NR_EPD
  • /SCWM/LM_NR_INDIRECT_LABOR_TASK
  • /SCWM/LM_PLAN_AREA
  • /SCWM/LM_PREPROCESSING
  • /SCWM/LM_WHS_NUMBER
  • /SCWM/PRC_LM_10
  • /SCWM/PRC_LM_15

2. Activate Labor Management
Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Activate Labor Management

3. Define External Process steps

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define External Process Steps

 

4. Assign External Process steps to warehouse Activity

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Assign External Process Step to Warehouse Activity

5.   Assign Planned Activity Areas

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Assign Planning Activity Areas

6. Define Number Range for Performance Document

Path : SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define Number Range for Performance Document

7. Define Delivery Date/Time for Preprocessing

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define Delivery Date/Time for Preprocessing

8. Activate Change Documents in Labor Management

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Activate Change Documents in Labor Management

  • Activate Change Documents for Processor

  • Activate Change Documents for Performance Document

  • Activate Change Documents for Time and Attendance

9. Define Processor Types

Path : SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Processor Types

10. Define Reporting Groups for Processors

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Reporting Groups for Processors

11. Define Work Categories

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Work Categories

12. Define Capacity Variants

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Shift Management -> Define Capacity Variants

13. Maintain Shift Management Defaults

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Shift Management -> Maintain Shift Management Defaults



14. Create a Processor

T.Code: /N/SCMB/PRR1

15. Assign User to BP created

16. Conditions for Engineered Labor Standards

T.code: /N/SCWM/LM_CE

17. Formula for Engineered Labor Standards

18. Determine Engineering Labor Standards

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Determine Engineered Labor Standards

Test :

Pre- requisites:
Create two deliveries and distribute them to EWM, ensuring each delivery has a different weight, one below 20 kg and one above 20 kg, to match the conditions we configured.

Let‚Äôs first take an example with a weight below 20 kg, execute it, and review the workload. After that, we‚Äôll do the same for a case above 20 kg.

Maintain Inbound Deliveries

T.code: /N/SCWM/PRDI

As you can see, the delivery mentioned above includes a handling unit weighing 4.400 kg. Let‚Äôs create the warehouse task for unloading and execute it through the RF screen to validate the processor‚Äôs performance.

Let‚Äôs create a warehouse Task using Monitor-

T.code: /N/SCWM/PRDI>> Inbound Delivery>>Follow on Functions>>Warehouse Task

By clicking ‚ÄúCreate,‚Äù the system generates a warehouse task to move the handling unit from the Door to the GR-ZONE (staging area). Next, let‚Äôs review the Warehouse Order for ‚ÄúLM Active.‚Äù As shown, the LM Active checkbox is enabled, indicating that Labor Management is activated for this step.

Now let‚Äôs execute the activity in RF screen
Path: Inbound>> Unloading>> Unload by Delivery

Upon scanning the HU, the system captures the start timestamp and initiates the timer to measure the total time taken by the associate or processor to complete the activity.

Once you scan the destination bin and confirm ‚ÄúYes‚Äù for Completely Unloaded, the timer stops. Now let‚Äôs review the workload in the monitor.

The screenshot above is from the workload monitor, which displays the execution details. As shown, the processor ‚ÄúNICK WILDE‚Äù executed the unloading task, with the recorded weight of 4.2 kg. The planned execution time is 5 minutes, which is a critical value derived from the condition and formula maintained in configuration steps 16 and 17.

The monitor also shows the actual execution details start and end timestamps, planned duration, and the actual duration taken by the processor. In this example, the processor took 7.467 minutes to complete the task, compared to the planned 5 minutes. Based on this variance, the system calculated the processor‚Äôs efficiency as 66.96%.

Now, let‚Äôs take another delivery with a weight of 42.200 kg and review how the system determines the planned execution time for unloading, using the same configuration rules from steps 16 and 17.

Let‚Äôs execute the step and find out the performance

After execution, the planned time is 7 minutes, calculated based on the configured formula. The actual duration recorded is 18.317 minutes, resulting in an efficiency of 38.22%, since the processor took significantly longer than the planned time.

Through these scenarios, we validated how SAP EWM Labor Management calculates planned, actual, and efficient metrics using condition-based formulas. By executing unloading tasks for deliveries below and above the 20 kg threshold, we observed how the system dynamically derives planned execution time and evaluates processor performance via RF-driven timestamps. Importantly, these calculations are not limited to weight alone any relevant operational parameter (such as quantity, HU type, product group, packaging material, distance, activity type, or process step) can be incorporated into the condition and formula framework.

This flexibility allows organizations to tailor labor standards to real-world warehouse processes. Overall, these examples demonstrate how workload monitoring offers clear visibility into performance, highlights gaps between planned and actual durations, and enables data-driven optimization of warehouse efficiency in SAP EWM.

entry.title: SAP Screen Personas 3.0 SP20: Enhancements to Flavor Management, BDT Support, and Adaptive Flavors
entry.content:
The latest update to SAP Screen Personas 3.0 with Service Pack 20 (SP20) introduces several powerful enhancements designed to make flavor creation, maintenance, and device-specific adaptation easier and more flexible than ever.
Below is a summary of the key improvements and how they benefit administrators, developers, and flavor builders.

1.  Copy a Flavor to Multiple Target Flavors

The former "Copy to Application ID" option has been enhanced and renamed to "Copy to Application ID or Flavor ID".
With this improvement, you can now copy a source flavor to target flavor. You can also you can apply the same source flavor to several target flavors in a single step, making mass flavor updates faster and more efficient.

When screens or transactions share similar layouts, you can reuse an existing flavor instead of starting from scratch.
For example: If you have a Display flavor and want to create a Change flavor, you can copy the Display flavor, adjust the fields that differ, and quickly finalize the Change version. This ensures consistency and significantly reduces development time.

Prerequisites

  • Personas Administrator role is required

  • Target flavors must already exist (either empty or with changes)

  • Source flavor must not contain an adaptive stack

For more details, refer to  Copy a Flavor to a Different Transaction in the documentation.
 
Additional  Options for BDT app flavors

BDT (Business Data Toolset) transactions often share identical detail screens but have different entry screens.
To support these scenarios,  an additional option has been introduced for BDT app flavors where the entry screen changes can be skipped during the copy process.
This allows flavor updates to be applied efficiently without impacting initial-screen behavior.

2. Adaptive Flavors for Custom Industrial Devices

Administrators can now define their own device list for adaptive flavor creation in SAP GUI for HTML and Slipstream Engine.

Until SP19, the device list was static and maintained exclusively by SAP. With SP20, administrators can register custom industrial devices used within their organization and specify attributes such as device width and pixel ratio. These values determine how an adaptive flavor is rendered for that specific device.  The newly added devices will be available to choose from list of devices while creating new adaptive flavors.

Additionally, in Slipstream Engine,the custom device created by the administrator becomes available in the Device Preview list, allowing designers to preview exactly how a flavor will appear on a custom company device.

Benefits

  • Enables greater flexibility in optimizing the user experience for rugged devices, handheld scanners, industrial tablets, and other specialized hardware.

  • Ensures that flavors are responsive and visually optimized for the intended device landscape.

  • Streamlines the design cycle and reduces trial-and-error.

For more information, see Devices.

3. BDT Mode Enabled by Default

With SP20, BDT Mode is now enabled by default, simplifying setup and configuration.

This means there is no need to manually set the ENABLE_BDT_MODE parameter in /PERSONAS/ADMIN when creating flavors for Business Data Toolset (BDT)‚Äìenabled transactions, such as Business Partner (BP) screens.

To support legacy flavors created without BDT mode enabled, a new parameter‚ÄîDISABLE_BDT_MODE‚Äîhas been introduced.

This ensures that administrators can preserve previous behavior and that legacy BDT flavors continue to function correctly after the SP20 upgrade.

For more information, refer note 2451049

4. Message Toast Support

In SP20 , a new scripting API command has been introduced for displaying non-interactive popup messages in SAP GUI for HTML similar to the "toast message" in SAPUI5.  Scripting API command was available only in slipstream engine with SP19. With this new command, you can now easily implement message toasts for simple scenarios, allowing for streamlined feedback that aligns with SAP Fiori standards. This addition helps enhance user experience by providing subtle, non-disruptive messages in SAP Screen Personas.

Example:  session.utils.showMessageToast("This is a toast message");

How it works

  • Shows a small popup message that disappears after a few seconds.

  • The message stays visible if the user hovers or taps on it.

Conclusion

The SP20 release brings meaningful enhancements that streamline flavor management, improve BDT handling, and provide greater flexibility for device-specific adaptations. Whether you‚Äôre managing complex environments or designing mobile-friendly screens, these features help deliver a more efficient and tailored user experience.

SP20 related notes: : https://me.sap.com/notes/3672078 

 

Learn more about SAP Screen Personas
  • Online training. The best way to learn the basics about SAP Screen Personas (Adapt UI for classic applications) is to take our free training course on the learning.sap.com platform: https://learning.sap.com/courses/adapting-the-ui-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-using-sap-screen-personas
  • Connect with your peers. Every other month, we have a group of customers that gather online to share best practices, demo their flavors, and answer each other‚Äôs questions. Experts from the product team also join to explain how to use the latest functionality. If you are interested in joining, you can sign up online to join the SAP Screen Personas practitioner forum. This will add you to the mailing list for the monthly meeting summaries. Please contact ‚ÄúPeter Spielvogel‚Äú or me directly if you want to join the monthly calls.
  • Product documentation. The SAP Screen Personas documentation, provides more clear , comprehensive and the latest information about the product.

Going forward with SAP Screen Personas

  1. If you are on SP18 or earlier, we recommend you upgrade now, ideally going directly to SP20.
  2. If you are not currently using SAP Screen Personas, why not?
    Worried that we won‚Äôt support it into the future? Don‚Äôt be.      We are supporting SAP Screen Personas functionality through at least 2040.
    Have other concerns about the roadmap for SAP Screen Personas? See if we answer them in our latest roadmap blog post .  
  3. SAP Screen Personas is now available with the Default Installation Stack of SAP S/4HANA 2025, Private Cloud Edition

entry.title: S/4HANA 2023 FPS3 Fully-Activated Appliance custom installation
entry.content:
This blog covers installation of (1) SAP S/4HANA server and (2) SAP NW JAVA / ADS server as shown in the graphic below. The installation is based on file restore and is different from the standard installs using SWPM.

Please refer to S/4HANA SQUARE ONE for other blogs

In this blog the procedure is simplified for hostname change and SID change. Also if you want to change instance number the command, screens show where you can change the instance number. This would make sense if your network cannot accommodate the unique hostname and SID. Also if it is a more permanent installation you may like to change SID and hostname.

If you want to do standard installation with no change in hostname and sid please refer to other blog In this blog the procedure is simplified for standard installation with NO HOSTNAME OR SID CHANGE. The advantage with this is that you don't have to do many of the steps related to SID change and it does make sense if you will be installing the instance temporarily.

This blog is based on a fresh installation of SUSE Linux for SAP OS without having any previous SAP instances created and deleted. I did not have to pre install hostagent, etc. There are mount points/links to be setup as shown in the right place in the directory structure. The steps in the guides provided with SAP Note 2041140 could be used as a reference in case there are issues specific to your environment. Just follow the steps below to install both systems shown in red square below:

Please find below the main note for ordering the appliance:
2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

PART1: SOFTWARE DOWNLOAD

Please download the software media from https://me.sap.com/softwarecenter
INSTALLATIONS & UPGRADES => By Alphabetical Index (A-Z) => S => SAP S/4HANA => SAP S/4HANA 2023 => S/4HANA FULLY-ACTIVATED APPLIANCE => SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 FA APPL

On SAP S/4HANA Server, download the 51058694_1 to 51058694_5  files and SWPM20SP22_3-80003424.SAR (or later).

On SAP NW JAVA / ADS server, download the 51058694_5, SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR and 51050829_JAVA_part 1 & 2 - NW 7.5 Java based SW Comp.

PART2: INSTALL SAP S/4HANA

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. For /sapmnt provide min 30GB, /hana/data space - min 500GB, /hana/log min 120GB. I have used /sapmedia - 200GB temporary separate mount that can be removed later.

WARNING: PLEASE NOTE THE MOUNT POINT ! This applies to S/4HANA 2023 FPS3 Fully-Activated Appliance with Media numbers 51058694_* with . HANA 2 SPS8 release 82 (may not apply to other FAA releases) , if you want to rename the SID, the mount point /hana/data, /hana/log and /hana/shared should be used instead of /hana/data/HDB, /hana/log/HDB and /hana/shared/HDB. Reason is - the hdblcm register_rename_system command will rename the filesystem for you. This applies for any other filesystem that contains DB SID, mount its parent directory and only applies to HANA DB. SAP filesystems continue to be mounted with target SID as before. After installation is completed, you can adjust the filesystems mount points if necessary according to your standard to keep it consistent for other systems. 

Plan the change of SID, hostname, instance number. Please refer to the notes below for reserved SIDs SAP Note 1979280 - Reserved SAP System Identifiers (SAPSID) with Software Provisioning Manager and hostnames SAP Note 611361 - Hostnames of SAP ABAP Platform servers
The table below shows standard SID and hostnames and what we are changing it to.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below. If you are changing hostname for db and sap add the standard and new hostname for DB but for SAP only provide new hostname. Also for J2E include the new hostname only as this is on separate instance. The standard hostname can be removed later as shown in the steps below. Please note that it has

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES Extract files 51058694_*  in /sapmedia

sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_1.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_2.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_3.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_4.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_5.ZIP

Allow approx 2 hours for extraction.

We will install Central system with DB and App on same server. Please move all *.tgz-* files (from 51058694_1 to 51058694_4) to /sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1

cd /sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
mv /sapmedia/51058694_2/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_2/*.tgz-* .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_3/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_3/*.tgz-* .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_4/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_4/*.tgz-* .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_5/*.tgz-* .

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

Please use command below to extract the database related archives:

sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia/# cd 51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1

cat dblog.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

Similarly extract the remaining files:

cat dbexe.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

It takes about an hour for extraction.

Below two Application related archives may be extracted on a separate app server for distributed installation. These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/S4H and /usr/sap/S4H so if you are changing the SID, then you will have to first extract to SID-S4H and then create links to your own SID like S4D

Then extract the files:
sid-hdd-s4d:/usr/sap #cd 51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
cat usrsap_s4h.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
cat sapmnt_s4h.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_5/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml


Follow this procedure as it is a known issue, please refer SAP Note 2082466 - Known Issues in SAP HANA Platform Lifecycle Management (HDBLCM)  (Issue# 69)

cd /hana/shared/HDB/HDB02/vhcalhdbdb
rm .daemon.ini.swp

vi daemon.ini
Edit section [localsecurestore] to change instances = 0

STEP 4: REGISTER DATABASE 

The HANA DB hdblcm register_rename_system command will rename the filesystem for you according to the new target SID for Hana database instance. HDB => HDD.

Execute HANA database specific steps as below:

sid-hdd-s4d: ##/hana/shared/HDB/hdblcm/hdblcm --action=register_rename_system

TIP: Places where you need to enter data is indicated, rest all are default options. Please note hdblcm now includes rename database host and a separate step with command to rename db host (hdblcm --action=rename_system --hostmap=vhcalhdbdb=vhcalhdddb) is not required. Also a separate step to rename mount points (hdblcm --action=register_rename_system) is not required.

This should bring up the database processes as below

sid-hdd-s4d: #/usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 02 -function GetProcessList

TIP: At this point it is necessary to install the HANA database license as the database will be started in restricted mode.

STEP 5: EXTRACT SWPM Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-hdd-s4d:/install #/sapmnt/S4D/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM20SP22_3-80003424.SAR

STEP 6: RENAME SAP SYSTEM Rename instance using sapinst

sid-hdd-s4d:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_ENFORCE_CRL=false SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcals4dci

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-hdd-s4d.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System S4H and Target System S4D:
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you dont want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen SAP HANA Database Connectivity enter Instance Number 02(or changed number) and Password Welcome_2Welcome_2. Click on Next.

If you don't install HANA DB license you will get error below. Install license using HANA Studio and continue. License is required if there is a database SID change..

At the screen SAP HANA Database Parameter you can change Schema User , DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM password. Please note it is also optional to change the schema user SAPHANADB password along with DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM users.

At the screen Database Schema accept schema SAPHANADB password and confirm Schema password Xxxxxxxn click on Next.

At the screen Rename Tenant Database click on Next

At the screen Secure Storage for Database Connection select HANA Secure User tore (hdbuserstore) click on Next 

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn
At the screen Secure Storage Key Generation accept radio button ‚Äì Individual Key (Recommended for Productive Systems) On the Next
At next screen Warning click OK
At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next
At the screen Install License Key keep unchecked Install License Key. Click on Next
TIP: It is much easier to install the license by providing the file than doing it later through the application.
At next screen Cleanup of Encryption Key checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
At next screen Cleanup of Operating System Users checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

TIP: In case you get this ERROR:

(1) Error occurs when executing command 'changekey' using the command line tool 'rsecssfx'.

RESOLUTION: Follow SAP Note 2800204 - SSFX-0362: Value file "-" does not start with the UTF-8 byte order mark

Ensure the environment variable LC_CTYPE of the user running sapinst is set as LC_CTYPE=en_US.
Stop the current sapinst and restart it. Continue with the existing option.

(2) You may get Warning below for rename of profile parameter. Found possible references to the source system in the profile directory of the target system /sapmnt/S4D/profile 

After sapinst process is finished you can manually start the SAP instance S4D

sid-hdd-s4d:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 01 -function StartSystem ALL
sid-hdd-s4d:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function StartSystem ALL

After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder and remove temporary links to S4H as well as temporary hostnames.

Standard users are as follows:
HANA DB ‚Äì Instance 02 SYSTEM /<Master Password> or as you changed in above
Web Dispatcher access : bpinst/Welcome1

STEP 7: POST STEPS Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf => Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Adapt HANA connections in DBACOCKPIT (nothing was required to be done here).

Host name / port in table HTTPURLLOC using tcode httpurlloc

Adapt RFC Connections

ABAP connections:
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_RFC
‚Ä¢ S4DCLNT100, S4DCLNT200, S4DCLNT400
‚Ä¢ S4D_RFC

HTTP connections:
‚Ä¢ ADS (pointing to the JAVA server after PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA /ADS)
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_HTTP
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_HTTPS
‚Ä¢ S4FIN_HTTPS

SAP Enable Now Web Assistant enter tCode /UI2/FLP_CUS_CONF

Adapt the Fiori notification URL. enter tCode /UI2/FLP_SYS_CONF

Adapt Enterprise Search

Apply product license keys

Install software product license key: Technical restrictions may apply if you don‚Äôt install the license. Use the link to obtain license key.
HANA DB license key can be installed via HANA Studio (Preferences -> License)
In SAP S/4HANA 1909 the license key is installed via SAP logon tCode SLICENSE

Further post-installation checks

Install SAP client tools on your local computers

You can take a full backup and remove the temporary links that were setup for S4H

In client 000 fix transport configuration. Enter tCode SE06 and reinstall CTS transport system, Change originals to S4D, Delete old TMS config, delete old versions of transport routes

Adapt any SAP parameters due to changed SID

The database should be with log mode overwrite and you may like to change that as needed.Please carry out the the other basis steps that are usually done with SID change/System refresh :

SPAD - Spool Administration
SCC4 - Client Administration - Logical System
RZ10- Instance profiles
SP01 - Spool delete old spool requests

PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA / ADS

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. Total filesystem needed is min 70GB for installation.

Plan the change of SID, hostname, instance number. Please refer to the notes below for reserved SIDs SAP Note 1979280 ‚Äì Reserved SAP System Identifiers (SAPSID) with Software Provisioning Manager and hostnames SAP Note 611361 ‚Äì Hostnames of SAP ABAP Platform servers

The table below shows standard SID and hostnames and what we are changing it to.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below:

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES

Extract files 51058694_5.ZIP  in /sapmedia

sid-j2d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_5.ZIP

We will install Java instance from files in  /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

cd /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/J2E; /usr/sap/J2E and /sybase/J2E. After these are extracted you can rename the filesystem or remount with changed mount points.

sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dblog.tgz-*  | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dbexe.tgz-*  | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat sapmnt_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat usrsap_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml

STEP 4: RENAME MOUNT POINTS You can take a full OS backup at this point and rename mount points or directories to /sybase/J2D; /sapmnt/J2D; /usr/sap/J2D. The old standard mount points do not have to exist. After reboot ensure all new renamed mount points are valid.

STEP 5 EXTRACT SWPM Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-j2d:/install #/sapmnt/J2D/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR

STEP 6 RENAME SAP SYSTEM Rename instance using sapinst

sid-j2d:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcalj2dci 

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-j2d.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At the screen Software Integrity click on Next

At screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System J2E and Target System J2D:
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen Database System Type keep the default selection SAP Adaptive Server Enterprise for Business Suite

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn

At the screen Operating System User for SAP Database Administrator enter the password for sybj2d and User ID and Click on Next

At the screen SAP ASE Database System Parameters accept or change ports and Click on Next

At the screen Database User Passwords enter the passwords for user sa, sapsa, sapsso, SAPSR3DB which is Welcome_2Welcome_2. Click on Next

At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next

At the screen Media Browser select the media Package Location and Click on Next

At next screen Cleanup of Operating System Users checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next

Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

After about 10mins, the installation process will stop at this point.

You may get Warning below for rename of profile parameter. Found possible references to the source system in the profile directory of the target system /sapmnt/J2D/profile 

Please take note and proceed.

After the sapinst installation is complete, you can manually start/stop the SAP Java instance J2D using old startsap / stopsap commands

sid-j2d:/install # su - j2dadm
sid-j2d:j2dadm > startsap

To access JAVA server as SAP Netweaver Administrator the URL is:
https://sid-j2d.dummy.nodomain:50000/nwa

Standard users are as follows:
JAVA Administrator ‚Äì Adminitstrator / <Master Password> ;
Java user BPINST/Welcome1

STEP 7: POST STEPS Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf - Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Apply product license keys if you haven't installed during swpm install step before. Technical restrictions may apply if you don‚Äôt install the license. Use the link to obtain license key. SAPNetweaver 7.5 J2EE license key has to be installed via SAP Netweaver Administrator

Further post-installation checks
Adapt any SAP parameters due to changed SID
After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder.

SUPPORT TICKETS:

If you have any difficulty downloading the media open OSS message using component XX-SER-SAPSMP-SWC. If you have issues with technical deployment open message with component BC-INS-SRN.

OTHER REFERENCES:

SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Create your SAP S/4HANA system in a fraction of the usual setup time
SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Demo Guides

Blogs with known issues (2022 / 2021 / 2020), continuously updated

2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

Thank you. Hope you enjoyed the installation.

Mahesh Sardesai
Product Expert ‚Äì S/4HANA

entry.title: Key differences between SAP S/4HANA and SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
If your organization runs SAP S/4HANA on-premise, you might be wondering what a move to the cloud really offers. SAP Cloud ERP Private (= SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) is designed to answer that question. It provides a single-tenant, SAP-operated S/4HANA system that combines the power and flexibility of your on-premise environment with the continuous innovation and managed operations of the cloud. 

This blog breaks down the key differences in simple, practical terms to help you understand what sets SAP Cloud ERP Private apart and how it can benefit your business. 

 

Why Move from On-Premise to the Cloud in general?

With today‚Äôs rapid pace of innovations, organizations are facing new opportunities along with new challenges, including the need to scale and adapt at extraordinary speed. However, legacy applications, including on-prem ERP systems, that once were the backbone of business operations, are holding back companies from taking advantage of these innovations due to outdated processes, disconnected data, and disparate systems. 

 

 

With the transformation to the cloud, organizations benefit from: 

  • Faster Innovation: Get immediate access to the latest capabilities as they are released, including core application updates and embedded AI with Joule. 
  • Better Productivity: Modernize the user experience with Fiori apps and the conversational AI assistant, Joule, helping teams work faster and more intuitively than with the traditional SAP GUI. 
  • Connected Insights: Simplify cross-company analytics with prebuilt, SAP-managed data products and ready-to-use intelligent applications. 
  • Lower Total Cost of Ownership (TCO): Let SAP operate your environment for enhanced security, resilience, and scalability, freeing up your team to focus on strategic business initiatives. 

You may ask yourself, what does this mean in detail, what are the benefits of moving to SAP Cloud ERP Private?   

Here‚Äôs a closer look at the specific advantages you gain by moving to SAP Cloud ERP Private. 

 

The 4 Pillars of Differentiation 

To begin with, SAP Cloud ERP Private is an essential part of SAP‚Äôs corporate strategy and delivers innovations in each of its domains: AI, Data and Apps, which is not the case with on premise products. 

There are four main key pillars that set SAP Cloud ERP Private apart from on-premise: 

Let‚Äôs go into the details of each pillar. 

 

1. Functionalities in and around the core 

The SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition unlocks new and exclusive capabilities that strengthen your core processes. These include: 

 

Existing Add-Ons: 

Powerful solutions like Central Procurement, Central Finance and Extended Service Parts Planning are available for new customers only with the transformation to SAP Cloud ERP Private. A new add-on, available since release 2025 FPS0, Integrated Business Communications, is available only for SAP Cloud ERP Private customers. It allows users to send communications to customers and suppliers using business partners directly from within SAP Cloud ERP Private, to design the communication and to track responses. In the upcoming Feature Pack Stack 1, it is planned to even initiate conversations from within business documents like a sales or purchase order. 

 

Planned Innovations: 

Look forward to SAP ERP Cloud Private only innovations such as multi-stage intercompany sales and stock transfer. 

This feature is designed to streamline logistics and finance across a complex corporate group with multiple entities, improving efficiency and transparency, and is planned with Feature Pack Stack 1 of 2025. It eliminates the limitation of Advanced Intercompany Sales, which enables business between two affiliates within one group only. 

 

Sustainability Solutions: 

In case of being on a transformation journey to SAP Cloud ERP Private, benefit from solutions like SAP Sustainability Control Tower, Sustainability Footprint Management, and Green Ledger to embed ESG data directly into your core business processes. 

 

Packaged Applications: 

The Cloud ERP Private package includes additional entitlements for business applications (like SAP Signavio and SAP Business Network), transformation tools, and extensibility with the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), accelerating your time to value. 

 

In general, we recommend going to SAP Road Map Explorer to find innovations that are delivered with SAP Cloud ERP Private and only with SAP Cloud ERP Private. 

 

2. Joule and Business AI 

This is where the future of ERP becomes tangible. SAP Cloud ERP Private delivers AI capabilities that are not available to on-premise customers. 

 

Joule, Your AI Copilot: 

Role-based AI assistants in Joule help your employees work faster and smarter. With providing a conversational interface, Joule performs four basic basic patterns: navigate to business context related transactions, information about how to do a specific action by consuming user assistance content, perform transactions on business documents and get analytical insights (requires SAP Analytics Cloud). These base skills are available across the lines of business in SAP Cloud ERP Private:  

 

 

For latest information about supported Joule content for SAP Cloud ERP Private, please check this note and this documentation.

 

Business AI:

Business AI in SAP Cloud ERP Private comes in two forms: AI features and AI agents, delivered across the lines of business: 

 

AI features use generative AI or AI services such as document extraction and personalized recommendations. These premium AI features go beyond simple commands, automating, accelerating and predicting business processes in SAP Cloud ERP Private. 

Examples are: 

The automatic creation of in-house repairs and repair objects by scanning incoming paper documents like purchase orders or packing lists:

 

The planning of resources and predictions of workload for picking and packing using historical and real-time data:

 

 

Monitoring and resolving sales order fulfillment issues by using generative AI: 

 

AI Agents (currently in Beta): These agents take AI a step further by proactively managing complex tasks and solving business challenges. Role-based AI assistants in Joule orchestrate agents, accelerate workflows, and drive connected business outcomes at scale.

Examples are: 
 
The Accounts Receivable Agent helps resolve overdue payments by analyzing balances and recommending actions:

 

The Maintenance Planner Agent continuously analyzes real-time data and suggests maintenance schedule adjustments, reprioritizing tasks and improving asset health: 

 

For latest information about supported Business AI features and agents for SAP Cloud ERP Private please visit the SAP Discovery Center and this note.

 

3. Unmatched Data Insights 

Instant access to structured and harmonized data in real-time is a prerequisite for faster decision-making, which is critical to staying competitive in today's business climate. At the same time, organizations struggle with scattered data lakes and various data sources that lack common semantic data integration, making it difficult for businesses to extract meaningful insights. 

With SAP Business Data Cloud we will step on this opportunity and deliver a unified data platform that centralizes and seamlessly integrates data from SAP and non-SAP sources all by persevering in its critical business context. 

How does this relate to SAP Cloud ERP Private? 

SAP Cloud ERP Private users benefit from SAP-managed data products, which are ready-to-use building blocks for analytics and reporting. These data products are delivered and maintained by SAP, saving time and effort compared to building custom solutions in on-premise environments. Prebuilt and curated data products turn raw sources into ready-to-run, semantically consistent building blocks you can trust, whereas on-premise users would have to create their data products on their own. 

 

SAP-Managed Data Products: 

Gain access to a growing library of over 140 pre-built, semantically aligned data products for SAP Cloud ERP Private. These are maintained by SAP and ready to use, significantly simplifying cross-solution analytics.  
For latest information on available data products, please visit SAP Business Accelerator Hub.   

 

Intelligent Applications: 

Data products are the basis for intelligent applications, which are pre-configured, ready-to-use and SAP-managed dashboards and analytics. These apps leverage SAP Analytics Cloud as the key front-end solution for visualization, simplifying the process of creating interactive reports and dashboards. Intelligent Applications reduce complexity, requiring only installation and role assignment for consumption. 

Example: 

Working Capital Insights  
An established SAP Analytics Cloud story, now embedded in the BDC data product concept to help finance teams optimize cash, DSO/DPO and working capital levers.

 

4. Excellence in cloud operations

With SAP Cloud ERP Private, SAP manages the system infrastructure, security, and lifecycle management. This means your team is freed from routine maintenance and can focus on driving business value, all while benefiting from the scalability and security of a modern cloud environment operated by SAP. 

 

  • Streamlined operations and support, enabling the handover of technical operations for your mission-critical system to SAP 
  • High availability of your mission-critical systems‚ÄØbased on a‚ÄØstandard service level agreement (SLA) of 99.7%‚ÄØfor your SAP Cloud ERP Private 
  • Lower total cost of ownership (TCO)‚ÄØthrough a‚ÄØsubscription-based model and the increased cost efficiency of shifting upfront‚ÄØcapital expenses to operating expenses 

 

Learn more about SAP Cloud ERP Private operations on‚ÄØsap.com 

 

Summary 

For organizations on SAP ERP or SAP S/4HANA on-premise, SAP Cloud ERP Private offers a clear path to modernization. It delivers faster innovation, real-time analytics and data insights, superior user experience with Joule and Fiori, powerful embedded AI features, and the operational simplicity of a managed service. With upcoming highlights like multi-stage intercompany processes and a rapidly expanding catalog of AI use cases and data products, it represents the next step in intelligent ERP. 

Which of these differentiating features, such as the AI Agents or the pre-built data products, seems most relevant to your business needs right now? 

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog. I hope it has helped clarify the key differences between the two products.

entry.title: How to write Table function in stranded way like SAP
entry.content:
How to Write CDS Table Functions the Standard SAP Way

In SAP S/4HANA, we cannot always express complex business logic using pure CDS syntax. To manage scenarios like long text processing, procedural calculations, or important joins, SAP uses CDS Table Functions implemented through AMDP.

While many developers create table functions on the fly, SAP sticks to a strict and consistent design pattern across its standard content. This approach ensures good performance, readability, upgrade safety, and transportability.

A useful way to grasp this standard is to look at how SAP builds transactional CDS views, especially those that use CDS Table Functions. By examining SAP-delivered objects like I_SalesOrderTP, we can clearly see the structure, naming conventions, annotations, and implementation method that SAP expects developers to follow.

This guide explains how SAP writes table functions, how they implement them using AMDP, and how they use them in CDS views. This will help you design your own extensions in the same way SAP does.

  1. Start with a Standard View: I_SALESORDERTP.
  • SAP provides many standard CDS views in S/4HANA.
  • To understand how SAP writes table functions, the easiest example is the view: I_SALESORDERTP
  • This is a Transactional Processing View, delivered by SAP.

   2. Locate the Table Function Used Inside the View.

  • Inside the view, you will notice SAP has used: with parameters (...).

When crafting Table Functions ", in the manner SAP does " consistently adhere to this structure:

Create a CDS Table Function with parameters.

Implement it via an AMDP class/method using native SQLScript.

Consume it in your final CDS view using with parameters.

Follow the exact naming, annotation, and structure shown in standard objects such as I_SalesOrderTP, I_PurchaseOrderTP, I_BillingDocumentTP, etc.

Following this pattern guarantees:

Best performance (native HANA execution)

Transportability and upgrade-safety

Consistency with thousands of standard SAP-delivered objects

Conclusion

It is a tried-and-true architectural best practice to use SAP's standard pattern for CDS Table Functions. You can align your custom developments with the same design principles used in core SAP objects like *I_SalesOrderTP*, *I_PurchaseOrderTP*, and *I_BillingDocumentTP* by defining a CDS Table Function with parameters, implementing its logic in an AMDP method using native SQLScript, and consuming it through a final CDS view.


This method guarantees that sophisticated logic runs directly on SAP HANA for maximum efficiency, stays neatly isolated from the consumption layer, and is resilient to upgrades and transports. More significantly, because it adheres to a well-known and extensively used standard, it makes your solution instantly comprehensible to other SAP developers.
